questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a responsibility assignment matrix (RAM)?

Choices.choicetext: To assign resources to project tasks

questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 9.2, a responsibility assignment matrix (RAM) is used to show the relationship between work packages or activities and project team members, aiding in resource allocation in Project Resource Management.

questions.QuestionText: Which process is part of the Closing process group?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.7, identifies Close Project or Phase as a key process in the Closing process group, which finalizes all activities across all Project Management processes.

questions.QuestionText: In procurement management, what is a key output of the Conduct Procurements process?
questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 12.2, the Conduct Procurements process results in selected sellers, which is essential for obtaining goods or services from external sources in Project Procurement Management.

questions.QuestionText: What is the definition of a project as per PMI?

Choices.choicetext: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 1.2, defines a project as a temporary endeavor with a beginning and end, undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result, distinguishing it from ongoing operations.

questions.QuestionText: Which technique is used to estimate activity durations?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 6.4, describes parametric estimating as a technique that uses a statistical relationship between historical data and other variables to estimate activity durations inProyecto Schedule Management.

questions.QuestionText: How does the WBS dictionary support project execution?

Choices.choicetext: It provides detailed descriptions, acceptance criteria, and responsible parties for each work package
It contains only the project glossary of terms
It replaces the need for a project schedule
It is optional documentation created only for audits

questions.Explenation: The WBS dictionary provides supporting detail for each WBS component including scope description, deliverables, activities, milestones, resources, cost estimates, quality requirements, acceptance criteria, and technical references (PMBOK Guide 7, Planning Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: In qualityoha management, what is the Plan Quality Management process primarily concerned with?
questions.Explenation: The PM BOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 8.1, states that the Plan Quality Management process identifies the quality standards relevant to the project and determines how to satisfy them in the Project Quality Management knowledge area.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of the Identify Risks process?

Choices.choicetext: To determine which risks may affect the project

questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7      th Edition, Section 11.2, the Identify Risks process determines the risks that might affect the project and documents their characteristics in the Project Risk Management knowledge area.

questions.QuestionText: Which factor is most important in stakeholder engagement?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 13.2,the emphasizes that effective communication is crucial for stakeholder engagement to manage expectations and achieve project success.

questions.QuestionText: What is a project baseline?

Choices.choicetext: The approved version of the project plan

questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition,use Section      4.2, a project baseline is the approved version of the scope, schedule, and cost that serves as a point of reference for performance measurement.

questions.QuestionText: How does the Control Scope process help in project management?

Choices.choicetext: By monitoring variances fromdiv the plan

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 5.6, describes the Control Scope process as monitoring the status of the project and product scope and managing changes to the scope biser baseline.

questions.QuestionText: What is the key output of the Develop Team process?
questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 9.3, the Develop Team process produces team performance assessments to improve team effectiveness in Project Resource Management.

questions.QuestionText: In cost management, what does CPI stand for?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 7.4.2.2, defines CPI (Cost Performance Index) as a measure of the cost efficiency of budgeted resources, used in earned value management.

questions.QuestionText: What is the main zadgoal of the Monitor Communications process?

Choices.choicetext: To ensure the information needs of the project are met

questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 10.3, the Monitor Communications process ensures that the projects communication activities align with the communication plan in Project Communications Management.

questions.QuestionText: Which of the following is a constraint in project management?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 2.3, lists time as a common project constraint that limits the schedule and affects project delivery.

questions.QuestionText: What does the Perform Integrated Change Control process inmonvolve?
questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4JT.6, Perform Integrated Change Control reviews all change requests, approves changes, and manages changes to the deliverables and project management plan.

questions.QuestionText: How is project success defined by PMI?

Choices.choicetext: By meeting the project objectives and stakeholder expectations
By completing the project under budget
By finishing the project on time

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 1.2.4, defines project success as delivering the project objectives while meeting key criteria zichtbaarsuch as scope, time, cost, and stakeholder satisfaction.

questions.QuestionText: What is the role of a project Commun management Information System (PMIS)?

Choices.choicetext: To collect, store, and distribute project information

questions.Explenation: According to the PMBiquBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.3, a PMIS is a standardized set of tools for collecting, storing, and distributing information, supporting project integration.

questions.QuestionText: In schedule management, what transitionsis a lead?

Choices.choicetext: An amount of time a successor activity can be advanced
A delay in the successor activity

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 6.6, defines a lead as the amount of time whereby a successor activity can be advanced with respect to a predecessor activity in the project schedule.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of the Plan Procurement Management process?

Choices.choicetext: To document purchasing decisions and identify potential sellers

questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 12.1, the Plan Procurement Management process documents the project's procurement decisions and identifies potential sellers in Project Procurement Management.

questions.QuestionText: Which knowledge area deals with managing project team composition?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 9, focuses on Project Resource Management, which includes planning, estimating, acquiring, developing, and managing the project team.

questions.QuestionText: What is a key input to the Develop Project Management philosophPlan process?
questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.2, the project charter is a key input to the Develop Project Management Plan process, providing the foundation for the overall plan.

questions.QuestionText: In risk           response planning, what is anuplemitigation strategy?

Choices.choicetext: Reducing the probability or impact of a threat
Transferring the risk to another party

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 11.5, describes risk mitigation as a strategy to reduce the probability or impact of a threat, as part of the Plan Risk Responses process.

questions.QuestionText: What does the term 'rollback' refer to in project scheduling?

Choices.choicetext: A technique to shorten the project schedule
A method tohyung increase project scope

questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 6.6, rollback is a scheduling technique used in network diagrams to analyze the project schedule and identify the critical path.

questions.QuestionText: Which process is used to ensure that the project will satisfy the needs for whichMu it was undertaken?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 5.5, explains that Validate Scope formally accepts the completed project deliverables and ensures they meet stakeholder needs.

Choices.choicetext: Using existing knowledge and generating new knowledge

questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.4, Manage LAS Project Knowledge involves using existing knowledge from the organization and generating new knowledge to achieve the project objective.

questions.QuestionText: In quality management, what is a control chart used for?

Choices.choicetext: To determine whether a process is stable or has predictable performance

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 8.3, uses control charts to monitor process variation and determine if a process is in control, as part ofProject Quality Management. In PMBOK 7, this aligns with the Delivery Performance Domain.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of the Perform Quality Assurance process?

Choices.choicetext: To audit the quality requirements and results from quality control measurements-money

questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 8.2, Perform Quality Assurance audits the quality requirements and the results from quality control measurements to ensure the project employs the planned quality processesRegistr.

questions.QuestionText: Which tool is commonly used in stakeholder analysis?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 13.1, recommends the Power/Interest Grid as a tool for stakeholder analysis to categorize stakeholders based on their power and interest in the project.

questions.QuestionText: What does the Control Costs process involve?

Choices.choicetext: Monitoring the project status to update the cost baseline,

questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 7.5, the Control Costs process monitors the status of the project to update the cost baseline and manage changes to the project budget.

questions.QuestionText: In project integration management, what is the output of the Monitor and Control Project Work process?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.5, lists change requests as a key output of the Monitor and Control Project Work process to address variances in project performance.

questions.QuestionText: What is a key characteristic of a projectized organization?

Resources are licensed shared across projects

questions.QuestionText: What is the main purpose of the Define Scope process?

Choices.choicetext: To develop a detailed description of the project and product
To control changes to the scope

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 5.3, states that the Define Scope process develops a detailed description of the project scope and product, guiding the project's execution.

questions.QuestionText: How does PMI define a program?

Choices.choicetext: A group of related projects managed in a coordinated way
A single project with multiple phases

questions.Explenation: According to the PM quyBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 1.2, a program is a group of related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.

questions.QuestionText: What is the first step in the risk management process?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 11.1, identifies Plan Risk Management as the first process, where the framework for managing risks on the project is established.

questions.QuestionText: In resource management, what is the output of the Estimate Activity Resources process?
questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 9.2 maxlen, the Estimate Activity Resources process produces activity resource requirements, detailing what resources are needed for each activity.

questions.QuestionText: What is a SWOT analysis used for in project management?

Choices.choicetext: To identify strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats

questions.QuestionText: oilsWhat is the primary benefit of the Plan Stakeholder Engagement process?

Choices.choicetext: To develop appropriate management strategies for engaging stakeholders

questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 13.2, the Plan Stakeholderenga Engagement process develops strategies to effectively engage stakeholders throughout the project life cycle.

questions.QuestionText: In cost management, what is a S-curve?

Choices.choicetext: A display of cumulative costs over time

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section  rumble7.4, describes an S-curve as a graph that shows cumulative costs, labor hours, or other quantities plotted againstin time, used for monitoring project performance.

questions.QuestionText: What does the Closipie e Project or Phase process include?

Choices.choicetext: Finalizing all activities to formally close the project

questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 4.7, the Close Project or Phase process finalizes all activities across all Process Groups to formally close, the project or phase.

questions.QuestionText: What is the key output of the Identify Stakeholders process?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 13.1, lists the stakeholder register as the key output of the Identify Stakeholders process, documenting stakeholder information.

questions.QuestionText: How is project variance measured?

Choices.choicetext: By comparing actual performance to the baseline resistance

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of the Develop Schedule process?

Choices.choicetext: To analyze activity sequences, durations, constraints, and resources to create the project schedule

questions.QuestionText: In procurement, what is a make-or-buy analysis?

Choices.choicetext: A technique to decide whether to make a product inside the organization or buy it externally
A method to estimate project costs

questions.QuestionText: What is a project deliverable?

Choices.choicetext: Any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability to perform a service

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 1.2, defines a project deliverable as a unique and verifiable product, result, or capability that must be produced to complete a process, phase, or project.

questions.QuestionText: Which process uses the tool of stakeholder mapping?
questions.Explenation: According to the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 13.1, stakeholder mapping is a tool used in the Identify Stakeholders process to visualize and categorize stakeholders.

questions.QuestionText: What is the key input to the Manage Communications process?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 10.2, identifies the communications management plan as a key input to the Manage Communications process, guiding how information is shared. In PMBOK 7, this aligns with the Stakeholder Performance Domain.

questions.QuestionText: In quality management, what is continuous improvement?

Choices.choicetext: An ongoing effort to improve products, services, or processes

questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 8, continuous improvement, often associated with Plan-Do-Check-Act, is an ongoing effort to enhance quality in Project Quality Management.

questions.QuestionText: What is lngthe main output of the Control Procurements process?
questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 12.3, lists work performance information as a key output of the Control Procurements process, providing insights on procurement status.

questions.QuestionText: How does the PMBOK Guide restructure processes?
questions.Explenation: In the PMBOK Guide, 7th+Y Edition, processes are restructured around principles and performance domains to provide a more flexible and principled-based approach to project management.

questions.QuestionText: What is a lag in Project Management?

Choices.choicetext: The amount of time an activity needs to be delayed

questions.Explenation: The PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 6.6, defines a lag as the minimum amount of time that the successor activity must be delayed relative to the predecessor activity.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of the Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis process?

questions.QuestionText: In resource management, what is the key benefit of the Acquire Resources process?

Choices.choicetext: To obtain the team necessary for the project

questions.QuestionText: What does the Term 'float' mean in project scheduling?

questions.Explenation: As per the PMBOK Guide, 7th Edition, Section 6.6, float (or slack) is the amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project finish date.

questions.QuestionText: What is the primary output of the Plan Risk Responses process?

A path with the least float

questions.QuestionText: What happens if a project proceeds without a formally approved project charter?

Choices.choicetext: The project lacks formal authorization, clear boundaries, and the PM has no documented authority
The project will be more efficient without extra documentation
Team members can define their own project scope

questions.Explenation: Without a project charter, there is no formal recognition of the project's existence, no documented authorization for the PM to use resources, and unclear project boundaries. This typically leads to scope issues, conflicts over authority, and stakeholder confusion (PMBOK Guide 7, Stakeholder Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: In managing a complex IT project, the project manager uses the Monitor and Control Project Work process. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 4.5, what is the most effective way to identify variances from the baseline?
questions.Explenation: Data analysis techniques, such as variance analysis, are essential in the Monitor and Control Project Work process as described in PMBOK Guide, Section 4.5, to compare actual performance against the project baseline.

questions.QuestionText: During scope management of a pharmaceutical project, the project manager needs to validate scope. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 5.5, what is the primary output that confirms the project scope is complete?
questions.Explenation: Accepted deliverables are the primary output of the Validate Scope process in PMBOK Guide, Section 5.5, indicating formal acceptance by the customer or sponsor of the completed project scope.

questions.QuestionText: A project involves creating a new product line, and the project manager is controlling scope. As per PMBOK Guide, Section 5.6, what tool and technique is most useful for monitoring changes to the scope baseline?
questions.Explenation: The configuration management system is a key tool and technique in Control Scope as outlined in PMBOK Guide, Section 5.6, ensuring that changes to scope are tracked and managed systematically.

questions.QuestionText: In schedule management for a manufacturing project, the project manager uses critical path method. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 6.6, what is the main risk associated with a near-critical path activity?
questions.Explenation: A near-critical path activity, as discussed in PMBOK Guide, Section 6.6, can lead to increased project duration if delays occur, emphasizing the need for close monitoring in Control Schedule.

questions.QuestionText: During project scheduling, the project manager determines the project float. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 6.5, how does free float differ from total float in schedule management?

Choices.choicetext: Free float is the time an activity can be delayed without affecting the project end date
Free float is the time an activity can be delayed without affecting successor activities
Total float is only for critical path activities

questions.Explenation: Free float, as defined in PMBOK Guide, Section 6.5, is the amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the early start of its successor, unlike total float which affects the project end date. In PMBOK 7, this aligns with the Planning Performance Domain.

questions.QuestionText: A cost management plan is being developed for an infrastructure project. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 7.1, what is the key input for determining the project's cost baseline?
questions.Explenation: Cost estimates are a key input in the Determine Budget process as per PMBOK Guide, Section 7.1, forming the basis for aggregating costs into the project's cost baseline.

questions.QuestionText: In controlling costs for a software development project, the project manager calculates the cost variance. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 7.4, what formula is used to compute cost variance (CV)?
questions.Explenation: Cost variance is calculated as CV = EV - AC in the Control Costs process, as specified in PMBOK Guide, Section 7.4, to measure cost performance against the baseline.

questions.QuestionText: For a quality assurance project, the project manager implements the Plan Quality Management process. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 8.1, what tool is essential for identifying quality requirements?
questions.Explenation: The quality management plan is essential in Plan Quality Management as per PMBOK Guide, Section 8.1, as it outlines the quality requirements and standards for the project.

questions.QuestionText: In hybrid projects, how can the WBS be adapted to support both predictive and agile work?

Choices.choicetext: Create fixed WBS elements for predictive components and use product backlog for adaptive components
Avoid using WBS altogether in hybrid projects
Create two completely separate WBS documents
Use agile for 50% of work packages and predictive for the rest, randomly assigned

questions.Explenation: Hybrid projects can integrate predictive WBS structures for well-defined components with agile artifacts like product backlogs for evolving requirements. The key is maintaining visibility across both approaches while leveraging their respective strengths (PMBOK Guide 7, Development Approach Performance Domain; Agile Practice Guide, Section 3.1.6).

questions.QuestionText: In a large-scale project involving multiple stakeholders, the project manager identifies potential risks associated with regulatory changes that could delay procurement activities. questions.QuestionText: During the Monitoring and Controlling phase of a software development project, the project manager notices that the earned value (EV) is $50,000, planned value (PV) is $60,000, and actual cost (AC) is $55,000. Based on PMBOK Guide concepts in Section 7 (Project Cost Management), what is the cost variance (CV) and its implication?

Choices.choicetext: CV = -$5,000; the project is over budget
CV = -$10,000; the project is under budget
CV = -$5,000; the project is under budget
CV = -$5,000; the project is over budget

questions.Explenation: Cost variance (CV) is calculated as EV minus AC, which is $50,000 - $55,000 = -$5,000, indicating the project is over budget. As per PMBOK Guide, Section 7.4.2.1, a negative CV signals that actual costs exceed earned value, requiring corrective actions.

questions.QuestionText: During stakeholder engagement in a merger project, the project manager identifies conflicting interests that could lead to scope creep. As per PMBOK Guide, Section 13 (Project Stakeholder Management), what primary input to the Manage Stakeholder Engagement process helps in addressing these conflicts?
questions.Explenation: The stakeholder register is a key input to the Manage Stakeholder Engagement process, as outlined in PMBOK Guide, Section 13.3, providing detailed information on stakeholders' interests and potential conflicts, enabling the project manager to develop targeted engagement strategies.

questions.QuestionText: In a high-risk IT implementation project, the project manager applies risk response strategies and decides to transfer risks related to cyber threats. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 11 (Project Risk Management), what contract type is typically used to transfer such risks effectively?
questions.Explenation: A fixed-price contract is commonly used for risk transfer, as described in PMBOK Guide, Section 11.5, where the seller assumes the risk of cost overruns, making it suitable for transferring risks like cyber threats to external vendors.

questions.QuestionText: The project manager is executing a project with limited resources and must optimize the resource calendar. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 9 (Project Resource Management), which technique from the Acquire Resources process ensures that resource allocation aligns with organizational policies and availability?
questions.Explenation: Pre-assignment is a tool and technique in the Acquire Resources process, as per PMBOK Guide, Section 9.2.2, which helps in aligning resource allocation with predefined availability and organizational policies, especially in resource-constrained environments. In PMBOK 7, this aligns with the Team Performance Domain.

questions.QuestionText: In a project involving global procurement, the project manager evaluates bids using source selection criteria. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 12 (Project Procurement Management), what key output of the Conduct Procurements process documents the rationale for selecting a particular seller?
questions.Explenation: Selected sellers is an output of the Conduct Procurements process, as detailed in PMBOK Guide, Section 12.2.3, which records the evaluation and selection decisions based on criteria, ensuring transparency in the procurement process.

questions.QuestionText: During the development of a project charter for a new product launch, the project manager incorporates business case analysis. Per PMBOK Guide,Ethical and Professional Conduct standards, how does the project manager ensure that the charter aligns with PMI's ethical guidelines?

Choices.choicetext: By conducting a stakeholder impact analysis
By verifying honesty in benefit-cost ratios
By performing a lessons learned review

questions.Explenation: PMI's Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct emphasizes honesty, so verifying accuracy in elements like benefit-cost ratios in the project charter ensures ethical alignment, as referenced in PMBOK Guide initiation processes and PMI ethical standards.

questions.QuestionText: A project manager is managing communications in a distributed team using various tools. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 10 (Project Communications Management), what advanced method from the Manage Communications process enhances information flow in a matrix organization?
questions.Explenation: Interactive communication is a key method in the Manage Communications process, as per PMBOK Guide, Section 10.1, promoting real-time exchange in matrix organizations to resolve issues and improve collaboration among team members.

questions.QuestionText: In a project with evolving requirements, the project manager uses progressive elaboration. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 1 (Introduction), how does this concept integrate with the Control Quality process to refine project deliverables?

Choices.choicetext: By iteratively updating the quality management plan
By focusing solely on initial scope

questions.Explenation: Progressive elaboration, as defined in PMBOK Guide, Section 1.2.2, allows for iterative refinement in the Control Quality process, ensuring deliverables are progressively improved based on ongoing quality assessments and feedback.

questions.QuestionText: The project manager encounters a scope baseline change due to unforeseen regulatory requirements. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 5 (Project Scope Management), what is the correct procedure for processing this through integrated change control?

Choices.choicetext: Directly update the project scope statement
Submit a change request for approval
Ignore if it's a minor adjustment

questions.Explenation: All changes must be processed via change requests, as per PMBOK Guide, Section 4.3 and 5.6, ensuring that the integrated change control system evaluates impacts on scope, time, and cost before approval.

questions.QuestionText: In resource management for a team-based project, the project manager identifies skill gaps. Per PMBOK Guide, Section 9, what tool from the Develop Tempora Team process is most effective for addressing these gaps?
questions.Explenation: semblTraining is a key tool in the Develop Team process, as outlined in PMBOK Guide, Section 9.3.2, which directly addresses skill gaps by enhancing team capabilities and improving overall project performance.

questions.QuestionText: During risk auditing in a manufacturing project, the project manager evaluates the effectiveness of risk responses. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 11, what output of the Monitor Risks process provides lessons for future projects?
questions.Explenation: Organizational process assets updates are an output of the Monitor Risks process, as per PMBOK Guide, Section 11.7, capturing lessons learned from risk audits to improve risk management practices in future projects.

questions.QuestionText: The project manager is closing a procurement contract and must ensure all obligations are met. Per.secret, but Per PMBOK Guide, Section 12, what document from the Control Procurements process confirms the contractor's performance?
questions.Explenation: Closed procurements is an output of the Control Procurements process, as detailed in PMBOK Guide, Section 12.3, documenting that all contractual obligations have been fulfilled and the contract is formally closed.

questions.QuestionText: In stakeholder management for a community development project, the project manager uses a salience model. According to PMBOK Guide, Section 13, how does this model help in prioritizing stakeholder engagement strategies?

Choices.choicetext: By assessing power, urgency, and legitimacy

questions.Explenation: The salience model, referenced in PMBOK Guide, Section 13.1, prioritizes stakeholders based on attributes like power, urgency, and legitimacy, enabling tailored engagement strategies to manage expectations effectively.

questions.QuestionText: The project manager applies agile principles in a software project, integrating with PMBOK Guide practices. Per Section 2, what key PMBOK concept must be adapted to support iterative development?
questions.Explenation: Progressive elaboration, as per PMBOK Guide, Section 1.2.2, allows for iterative refinement in agile environments, ensuring that project plans evolve with changing requirements.}, {

questions.QuestionText: Product Management requested for your consumer product design to have different size options. However, there has been a recently imposed deadline to complete all designs in the next three weeks. To ensure on-time delivery, you propose to Product Management to scope the product's design to include only one size, which is already 90% completed and very likely to be completed within the given time frame. Which risk response strategy did you use to keep your project on track?
questions.Explenation: The risk response strategy you used is Avoid. Because you de-scoped the project's work to only one size configuration, you're 'avoiding' and eliminating the threat of having to complete multiple designs in a very short time period. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 123-124)

questions.QuestionText: You have been assigned as the Project Manager in charge of building a new construction home in the city. The charter has been approved, and you're in the process of creating your stakeholder register. Of the following, which is the best information to include in this document?

Choices.choicetext: Lessons learned from managing previous stakeholders

questions.Explenation: The Stakeholder Register contains information about the stakeholder's identification and assessment, such as their: (1) Identification: Name, Role, and Contact Information, (2) Assessment: Communication needs and frequency, expectations, and power/interest level. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 185)

questions.QuestionText: After your Engineering team completed analyzing data from testing the design, you decided to upload this report into the company's Electronic Management System for everyone's access 24/7. As the project manager, what communication method did you use in this scenario?
questions.Explenation: There are three primary methods of communication: Push, Pull, or Interactive. Push Communication is for one-way communications with stakeholders, where information is directly sent to individuals through emails or a voice mail. Pull Communication is when a team member must visit a website (such as a Google Drive or Sharepoint folder) or a repository to retrieve the document. In this question, the best answer is Pull Communication. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 13)

questions.QuestionText: It's the 5th week of your project and your Team is meeting with the customers to obtain their feedback on the newly iterated design. The Team would like to make sure that the product features are being prioritized based upon their needs and obtaining feedback to groom the product backlog. In this example, what type of project management approach is being used?
questions.Explenation: In an Agile environment, the team works in a series of iterations/cycles called 'sprints' to develop a fully functional product, which is based upon prioritized features in the product backlog. (PMBOK Guide 7th Edition, Pg 38)

questions.QuestionText: You are leading a new project to expand a restaurant chain in a new location. Your Management Team has notified you that the business is ramping up, and that the current equipment will not be enough to meet the demand of new customers. Unfortunately, the scope of your project plan only included procuring smaller equipment. What should you do next to ensure the project's success?

Choices.choicetext: Update the Cost Baseline with the additional funding required
Make changes to the project schedule based upon delivery of the equipment
Document this assumption in the Assumption Log, and submit a formal Change Request to procure additional equipment

questions.Explenation: Before you can procure additional equipment which will require additional funding outside of your originally approved Project Budget, a formal Change Request must be submitted, reviewed, and approved by the Change Control Board.

questions.QuestionText: You are discussing with your team what strategy to use for following the organization's procedures to achieve the quality goals. What type of project management plan are you creating?
questions.Explenation: The Quality Management Plan is created during the Planning phase of your project, and is used to document how to effectively manage your project's quality from planning to delivery of your final product to the customer. Quality is the extent that the project meets its requirements. (PMBOK Guide 7e, Pg 186)

questions.QuestionText: You've been recently assigned as the Project Manager to lead a team to develop a new consumer product. You've finished planning the project's scope, schedule, and budget, and now your team is beginning to complete all the work to create the product. What Process Group are you working in?
questions.Explenation: The process group in question is tied to Execution, in which your team is working to complete ALL the work and scope defined in the project management plan. Your goal is to lead the team during this phase so that all the project's requirements are being satisfied. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 171)

questions.QuestionText: Leadership would like to demo the prototypes to the customers by end of Q2 this year. However, from reviewing your project's schedule, several activities on the critical path have been delayed. Specifically, mechanical design and testing activities have been delayed by three weeks. To prevent this from negatively affecting this due date, what should you do first?

Choices.choicetext: Communicate to Leadership that the deadline will not be met
Ask Leadership for additional Engineering resources
Request for a deadline extension to complete the prototypes
Analyze opportunities to either fast-track or compress the schedule

questions.Explenation: This question is asking what should you do FIRST. As the Project Manager, the first thing that you want to do is to understand the schedule and identify what activities can be compressed or if activities can be accelerated & fast-tracked. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 58-62)

questions.QuestionText: During which Team Development Stage of the Tuckman ladder should a project manager focus on engaging the team members, addressing concerns, and resolving conflicts to help create a productive environment?
questions.Explenation: The key word here is 'Tuckman Ladder'. Use the Process of Elimination to figure out which answer choice best corresponds to the Tuckman Ladder Stage of 'creating a productive environment' for the Team and 'resolving conflicts.' The answer choice which best aligns with this is Storming. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 166)

questions.QuestionText: You and your Team are a couple months into the project, and everyone is focused on accomplishing the goals of the project and committing to the success of the project. All issues and roadblocks are being resolved in a timely manner, and everyone is highly engaged. What stage of the Tuckman Ladder is your Team navigating through?
questions.Explenation: The Team is operating like a 'well oiled machine'. Everyone is helping each other and building confidence with each other, and acting like a high 'performing' team. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 166)

questions.QuestionText: Your Team is following an Agile developmental approach to create a new software application. For this project, your project deliverables will be created in what type of fashion?
questions.Explenation: Products are created in an incremental and iterative approach when using an Agile methodology. An Agile lifecycle is iterative in nature. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 38)

questions.QuestionText: In an Agile based project, which of the following is not a true statement?

Choices.choicetext: In an Agile environment, the Project Manager typically follows a Servant Leadership approach
Agile Teams are composed of a large group of team members, of more than 10 individuals
Agile Teams self-organize and establish their own goals
Agile Teams are comprised of cross-functional team members, a Product Owner, and a Team Facilitator

questions.Explenation: All of the answer choices except B are true statements. Agile Teams typically consist of a small group of team members (less than 9 individuals). (Agile Practice Guide pg 39)

questions.QuestionText: In this type of approach, you and your Team use short 4-week iterations to create a deliverable product for your customer. This iteration will then repeat to refine and further add prioritized features to the product. This approach is best called
questions.Explenation: Short 4-week iterations also known as sprints, are typically used in the Agile approach. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 38)

questions.QuestionText: In an adaptive environment, which of the following is NOT a true statement?

Choices.choicetext: The project manager should help create a collaborative environment
It is recommended for the team members to have a narrow skillset
It is recommended for the team member to have a broad skillset
Customers are continuously engaged to provide feedback on project deliverables

questions.Explenation: Team members in an adaptive environment are recommended to have a broad specialization. (Agile Practice Guide)

questions.QuestionText: Your Leadership would like to follow the Agile Methodology to develop a new software application. They would like to visually track the team's work and manage everyone's work in progress. As the project manager, what would be the best approach to recommend for leading this project?
questions.Explenation: Kanban is the best choice here, since this allows the team to visualize everyone's workflow, and identify the team's Work-In-Progress without having to follow sequential constrained series of steps, like the Predictive Waterfall Approach. (Agile Practice Guide Pg 12; PMBOK Guide 7th Edition Pg 109)

questions.QuestionText: Your team has started procuring parts to build the mechanical assembly of the product. However, the Business Analyst discovers that one crucial component is missing, which needs to be included in the product's design. To include this new requirement in the project's plan, what should you do next as the project manager?

Choices.choicetext: Conduct a retrospective with the team
Hold a daily standup to discuss issues & roadblocks
Implement the new requirement in the product's design

questions.Explenation: As a Project Manager, you do NOT want to immediately implement a change to your project's plan without submitting a formal Change Request and obtaining approval from the Change Control Board. The process for Change Control should be outlined in the Change Control Plan, and documents how to implement and authorize changes. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 166)

questions.QuestionText: You are working as the Business Analyst on the project, and you have identified that there are more than 50 people involved in the project's activities. You're collecting requirements, and you need to communicate this information to different stakeholders. To ensure the right information gets communicated appropriately, what is the best action to take as the Business Analyst?

Choices.choicetext: Follow the organization's policies and procedures
Request the project manager to send out the communication
Collaborate with the project manager to understand the stakeholders' needs

questions.Explenation: It's very important to understand the needs of the individuals on your project. Each person may have different expectations with how they would like to receive information. It's in the best interest to work with the Project Manager to investigate and determine who needs what information, how the information should be communicated, and the frequency of communication. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 11-13)

questions.QuestionText: A new Six Sigma Initiative Project has been initiated to improve a software application and decrease costs. The Sponsor has developed the charter to align expectations with all key stakeholders. Who is responsible for communicating and managing communications with everyone?
questions.Explenation: Make sure you understand the roles and responsibilities of a Business Analyst. In this case, it is NOT the responsibility of the Business Analyst to manage communications with ALL key stakeholders. This is the role & responsibility of the Project Manager to properly manage the stakeholders throughout the entire project's life cycle, and to engage them appropriately per the Stakeholder Engagement Plan. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 8-9)

questions.QuestionText: As the Business Analyst on the project, you're working with the team to identify best practices and ways to improve the process or team's performance. Which approach would be the best way to gather this feedback from the team?
questions.Explenation: The lessons learned meeting is used to identify and share knowledge gained during a project, to help improve the team's performance, and to capture best practices that can be used for future implementations. This is usually held with the entire team present, instead of meeting individually with specific stakeholders. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 127, 180)

questions.QuestionText: You're supporting a project as the Business Analyst, and from working with the Project Manager, you identify that you'll need the support of one of the Managers to obtain resources to complete all engineering work. This Manager has a high level of power and a high level of interest. What is the best way to manage this stakeholder?

Choices.choicetext: Manage closely by inviting them to discussions
Satisfy their needs through periodic 1-on-1 meetings

questions.Explenation: Stakeholders with high levels of influence and power should be involved in important discussions, and provided any information they need to move the project forward. The best way to do this is to manage their expectations closely. These types of stakeholders will be extremely motivated to drive the project's success forward and to influence others to ensure a positive outcome. (PMBOK 7th Edition, pg 12-13, 177)

questions.QuestionText: How many principles of project management are identified in the PMBOK Guide 7th Edition?
questions.Explenation: PMBOK Guide 7th Edition identifies 12 principles of project management that guide behaviors and actions of project professionals.

questions.QuestionText: What does the stewardship principle in PMBOK 7 emphasize?

Choices.choicetext: Acting responsibly with integrity, care, and trustworthiness

questions.Explenation: The stewardship principle states that project professionals should act responsibly with integrity, care, and trustworthiness while maintaining compliance (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How many performance domains are described in PMBOK Guide 7th Edition?
questions.Explenation: PMBOK Guide 7th Edition describes 8 performance domains: Stakeholder, Team, Development Approach, Planning, Project Work, Delivery, Measurement, and Uncertainty.

questions.QuestionText: What is an 'outcome' according to PMBOK Guide 7?

Choices.choicetext: An end result or consequence of a process or project

questions.Explenation: An outcome is an end result or consequence of a process or project, focusing on benefits and value rather than just outputs (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a 'system for value delivery' in PMBOK 7?

Choices.choicetext: A collection of strategic business activities aimed at building and advancing an organization
A software tool for project tracking

questions.Explenation: A system for value delivery includes portfolios, programs, projects, products, and operations that work together to create organizational value (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What are the four values in the Agile Manifesto?

Choices.choicetext: Individuals and interactions, working software, customer collaboration, responding to change

questions.Explenation: The Agile Manifesto values: Individuals and interactions over processes; Working software over documentation; Customer collaboration over contracts; Responding to change over following a plan.

questions.QuestionText: What is a Sprint in Scrum?

Choices.choicetext: A fixed-length iteration, typically 2-4 weeks, to deliver a product increment
A project phase lasting several months

questions.Explenation: A Sprint is a fixed-length timebox (usually 2-4 weeks) during which the Scrum team works to complete a set of product backlog items (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the Product Backlog in Scrum?

Choices.choicetext: An ordered list of everything needed in the product

questions.Explenation: The Product Backlog is a prioritized list of features, requirements, enhancements, and fixes that constitute the work to be done on a product (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Daily Standup (Daily Scrum)?

Choices.choicetext: A brief daily meeting where the team synchronizes activities and plans for the next 24 hours

questions.Explenation: The Daily Standup is a short 15-minute meeting where team members share what they did yesterday, what they'll do today, and any impediments (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Retrospective in agile?

Choices.choicetext: A meeting to reflect on the team's process and identify improvements

questions.Explenation: A Retrospective is a regular meeting where the team reflects on what went well, what didn't, and what improvements to make (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Kanban board used for?

Choices.choicetext: Visualizing workflow and limiting work in progress

questions.Explenation: A Kanban board visualizes work as it flows through various stages and helps teams manage work-in-progress limits (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a User Story in agile?

Choices.choicetext: A short description of a feature from the user's perspective

questions.Explenation: A User Story describes a feature from the end user's perspective, typically formatted as: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit] (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of Sprint Planning?

Choices.choicetext: To determine what work will be completed in the upcoming Sprint
To review completed work with stakeholders

questions.Explenation: Sprint Planning is an event where the Scrum team determines which backlog items will be worked on during the Sprint (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: Who is the Product Owner in Scrum?

Choices.choicetext: The person responsible for maximizing the value of the product and managing the backlog
The project sponsor who provides funding
The developer who writes the most code

questions.Explenation: The Product Owner is accountable for maximizing the value of the product and is the sole person responsible for managing the Product Backlog (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the role of a Scrum Master?

Choices.choicetext: A servant leader who helps the team follow Scrum practices and removes impediments
The team manager who assigns tasks
The technical lead who makes all design decisions

questions.Explenation: The Scrum Master is a servant leader who helps the team understand Scrum, facilitates events, and removes impediments (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the focus of the Stakeholder Performance Domain?

Choices.choicetext: Engaging stakeholders to understand their needs and expectations

questions.Explenation: The Stakeholder Performance Domain focuses on activities and functions related to stakeholder engagement (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What does the Team Performance Domain address?

Choices.choicetext: Building a high-performing project team culture and environment

questions.Explenation: The Team Performance Domain addresses activities for establishing team culture, building high-performing teams, and leadership (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the focus of the Planning Performance Domain?

Choices.choicetext: Organizing and coordinating throughout the project lifecycle
Only creating the initial project plan

questions.Explenation: The Planning Performance Domain addresses activities for organizing and coordinating work across the project, including initial and ongoing planning (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What does the Delivery Performance Domain focus on?

Choices.choicetext: Delivering the project scope, quality, and expected outcomes

questions.Explenation: The Delivery Performance Domain addresses activities for delivering the scope, quality, and outcomes that the project was undertaken to achieve (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the focus of the Measurement Performance Domain?

Choices.choicetext: Assessing project performance and taking appropriate actions

questions.Explenation: The Measurement Performance Domain addresses activities for assessing project performance and taking appropriate corrective actions (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What does the Uncertainty Performance Domain address?

Choices.choicetext: Risk and uncertainty associated with the project and its environment

questions.Explenation: The Uncertainty Performance Domain addresses activities and functions associated with risk and uncertainty in the project (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What does the Development Approach and Life Cycle Performance Domain address?

Choices.choicetext: The development approach, cadence, and project phases

questions.Explenation: This domain addresses activities for establishing the development approach, delivery cadence, and project life cycle phases (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the Project Work Performance Domain focused on?

Choices.choicetext: Establishing project processes and managing physical and virtual resources

questions.Explenation: The Project Work Performance Domain addresses activities for establishing processes, managing resources, and fostering a learning environment (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a predictive life cycle?

Choices.choicetext: A traditional approach with bulk of planning upfront, executed in a single pass
A life cycle with no planning
A method for predicting lottery numbers

questions.Explenation: A predictive life cycle is a traditional approach where planning occurs upfront and the project is executed sequentially (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is an iterative life cycle?

Choices.choicetext: An approach that allows feedback on unfinished work to improve and modify it

questions.Explenation: An iterative life cycle allows feedback for unfinished work to improve and modify that work through successive prototypes (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is an incremental life cycle?

Choices.choicetext: An approach that provides finished deliverables the customer can use immediately

questions.Explenation: An incremental life cycle provides finished deliverables that customers can use immediately, focusing on delivering value in portions (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is an agile life cycle?

Choices.choicetext: An approach that is both iterative and incremental to refine work and deliver frequently
A life cycle with no documentation
A project with only one phase

questions.Explenation: An agile life cycle combines iterative and incremental approaches to adapt to change and deliver value frequently (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a hybrid life cycle?

Choices.choicetext: A combination of predictive, iterative, incremental, and/or agile approaches
A life cycle for hybrid vehicles only
A project without any life cycle

questions.Explenation: A hybrid life cycle combines elements of different approaches to achieve project goals based on context (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a timebox in agile?

Choices.choicetext: A fixed period of time allocated for an activity or iteration

questions.Explenation: A timebox is a fixed period of time during which work is performed. In Scrum, Sprints are timeboxes (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is velocity in agile?

Choices.choicetext: The amount of work a team completes during a typical iteration
The speed of the project sponsor's car

questions.Explenation: Velocity is a measure of the amount of work (often in story points) a team can complete during a single iteration (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is Work in Progress (WIP) in Kanban?

Choices.choicetext: The amount of work items currently being processed

questions.Explenation: WIP refers to work items that have been started but not yet completed. Kanban uses WIP limits to improve flow (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a burndown chart?

Choices.choicetext: A chart showing remaining work versus time in an iteration

questions.Explenation: A burndown chart shows the amount of work remaining over time, helping teams track progress toward completing iteration goals (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a burnup chart?

Choices.choicetext: A chart showing work completed versus total work over time

questions.Explenation: A burnup chart shows cumulative work completed against total scope, making scope changes visible over time (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is servant leadership?

Choices.choicetext: A leadership approach focused on serving and supporting the team

questions.Explenation: Servant leadership focuses on the growth and well-being of team members, removing impediments and enabling success (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is Definition of Done (DoD)?

Choices.choicetext: A shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete

questions.Explenation: Definition of Done is a team's shared understanding of what criteria must be met for a product increment to be considered complete (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is an Epic in agile?

Choices.choicetext: A large user story that can be broken down into smaller stories

questions.Explenation: An Epic is a large body of work that can be broken down into smaller, more manageable user stories (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Sprint Review?

Choices.choicetext: A meeting to demonstrate completed increment and gather feedback

questions.Explenation: The Sprint Review is held at the end of a Sprint to demonstrate the increment and collect feedback from stakeholders (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of an information radiator?

Choices.choicetext: To display project information visibly for all team members

questions.Explenation: An information radiator is a visible display of key project information that anyone can see at a glance, like a task board or burndown chart (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is tailoring in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Adapting the development approach to fit the project context

questions.Explenation: Tailoring is the deliberate adaptation of project approach to suit the specific context of the project (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)?

Choices.choicetext: The smallest version of a product that delivers value and allows learning
The final product with all features

questions.Explenation: An MVP is the minimum set of features needed to learn about product viability and gather customer feedback (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is continuous integration?

Choices.choicetext: Frequently merging code changes into a shared repository

questions.Explenation: Continuous integration is the practice of frequently integrating code changes, enabling early detection of problems (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a cross-functional team?

Choices.choicetext: A team with all skills needed to complete the work without external dependencies
A team that works in multiple offices

questions.Explenation: A cross-functional team has all the competencies needed to accomplish the work without depending on others (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the triple constraint in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Scope, time, and cost as interdependent project constraints

questions.Explenation: The triple constraint recognizes that scope, time, and cost are interdependent - changing one affects the others.

questions.QuestionText: What is the difference between a project and operations?

Choices.choicetext: Projects are temporary; operations are ongoing and repetitive

questions.Explenation: A project is a temporary endeavor to create a unique result, while operations are ongoing, repetitive activities (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a program in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Related projects managed together to obtain benefits not available individually

questions.Explenation: A program is a group of related projects managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a portfolio in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Projects, programs, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives

questions.Explenation: A portfolio is a collection of projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is Enterprise Environmental Factors (EEF)?

Choices.choicetext: Conditions not under the project team's control that influence the project

questions.Explenation: EEFs are conditions that can enhance, constrain, or influence the project but are typically outside the project team's control (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is Organizational Process Assets (OPA)?

Choices.choicetext: Plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases specific to the organization

questions.Explenation: OPAs include plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases that can be used to influence project success (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Sprint Retrospective?

Choices.choicetext: A meeting for the Scrum team to inspect itself and create improvement plans

questions.Explenation: The Sprint Retrospective is an opportunity for the team to inspect itself and create a plan for improvements (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is continuous delivery?

Choices.choicetext: The practice of keeping code in a deployable state at all times

questions.Explenation: Continuous delivery ensures that software can be released to production at any time, reducing deployment risks (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is pair programming?

Choices.choicetext: Two developers working together at one workstation

questions.Explenation: Pair programming is an XP practice where two developers work together - one writes code while the other reviews (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is test-driven development (TDD)?

Choices.choicetext: Writing tests before writing the code to be tested

questions.Explenation: TDD is the practice of writing automated tests before writing the production code, ensuring code is testable (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is refactoring?

Choices.choicetext: Improving internal structure of code without changing its external behavior

questions.Explenation: Refactoring improves code structure for better maintainability without altering its visible behavior (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a value stream?

Choices.choicetext: All activities required to deliver value to the customer

questions.Explenation: A value stream includes all the steps from initial concept to delivery that are necessary to deliver value to the customer (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a story point in agile estimation?

Choices.choicetext: A unit of measure for expressing the effort required to implement a user story
A paragraph in a story book

questions.Explenation: Story points are a relative unit of measure used to estimate the effort required to implement a user story (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is Planning Poker?

Choices.choicetext: A consensus-based estimation technique using cards
A card game played during breaks

questions.Explenation: Planning Poker is an agile estimating technique where team members use numbered cards to estimate effort collaboratively (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a project baseline?

Choices.choicetext: The approved version of scope, schedule, or cost used for comparison
The bottom of a construction site

questions.Explenation: A baseline is the approved version of a work product used as a basis for comparison against actual performance (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the Iron Triangle in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Another name for the triple constraint (scope, time, cost)

questions.Explenation: The Iron Triangle represents the triple constraint of scope, time, and cost that must be balanced in projects.

questions.QuestionText: What is a pull system in Kanban?

Choices.choicetext: Work is pulled when there is capacity, rather than pushed based on a plan

questions.Explenation: In a pull system, new work is only started when there is capacity to do it, rather than pushing work based on projections (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What does 'Inspect and Adapt' mean in agile?

Choices.choicetext: Regularly examining work and processes to make improvements

questions.Explenation: Inspect and Adapt is a core agile principle of regularly reviewing completed work and team processes to improve (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the primary purpose of the PMI Code of Ethics?

Choices.choicetext: To establish expectations for moral conduct based on responsibility, respect, fairness, and honesty

questions.Explenation: The PMI Code of Ethics establishes expectations based on four values: Responsibility, Respect, Fairness, and Honesty (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is cadence in project management?

Choices.choicetext: The rhythm or regular timing of project activities and events

questions.Explenation: Cadence refers to the rhythm of project activities, such as the regular timing of iterations or releases (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project manager notices team members are hesitant to share problems. Which PMBOK 7 principle should guide their response?

Choices.choicetext: Create a collaborative project team environment

questions.Explenation: The principle of creating a collaborative team environment includes fostering psychological safety where team members feel comfortable sharing concerns (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: When should a project manager consider tailoring the project approach?

Choices.choicetext: When the standard approach doesn't fit the project's unique context
Never - always follow the standard exactly
Only when the sponsor requests it

questions.Explenation: Tailoring should be considered when the project context requires adaptation of the methodology for better fit (PMBOK Guide 7, Tailoring principle).

questions.QuestionText: A project has high uncertainty in requirements. Which life cycle approach is most appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: Predictive life cycle with detailed upfront planning

questions.Explenation: Agile and iterative approaches are designed to handle uncertainty through frequent feedback and adaptation (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What should a project team do when they encounter an ambiguous requirement?

Choices.choicetext: Engage with stakeholders to clarify and refine the requirement

questions.Explenation: The stakeholder engagement principle emphasizes working with stakeholders to understand and clarify their needs (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How does the 'focus on value' principle guide project decisions?

Choices.choicetext: Decisions should be evaluated based on their contribution to business value

questions.Explenation: The focus on value principle ensures that project activities deliver meaningful outcomes aligned with stakeholder expectations (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team is using Scrum but requirements rarely change. What should they consider?

Choices.choicetext: Evaluate whether a predictive or hybrid approach might be more suitable

questions.Explenation: When requirements are stable, a predictive approach may be more efficient; agile provides value when change is expected (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the primary benefit of short iterations in agile?

Choices.choicetext: Faster feedback and ability to adapt to changes

questions.Explenation: Short iterations enable frequent feedback, allowing teams to adapt to changes and reduce wasted effort (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: When is a hybrid approach most beneficial?

Choices.choicetext: When parts of the project have different uncertainty levels or characteristics
When the team doesn't understand agile

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches are valuable when different parts of a project have varying levels of certainty or different needs (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should a project team respond when a high-priority risk materializes?

Choices.choicetext: Implement the planned risk response and update stakeholders
Ignore it and hope it resolves
Wait for sponsor approval before any action

questions.Explenation: The Uncertainty Performance Domain emphasizes having response plans and acting when risks materialize (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What determines whether to use iteration-based or flow-based agile?

Choices.choicetext: Team preferences, work consistency, and stakeholder needs for planning

questions.Explenation: Iteration-based agile uses timeboxes; flow-based agile (Kanban) is better for variable work sizes and continuous delivery (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A stakeholder requests a major scope change mid-project. What should happen first?

Choices.choicetext: Evaluate the impact on scope, schedule, cost, and other constraints

questions.Explenation: Change requests should be evaluated for their impact on project constraints before approval decisions (PMBOK Guide 7, Project Work Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of WIP limits in Kanban?

Choices.choicetext: To prevent overloading the team and improve flow

questions.Explenation: WIP limits prevent multitasking overload, identify bottlenecks, and improve workflow efficiency (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How does the Product Owner prioritize the backlog?

Choices.choicetext: Based on business value, risk, dependencies, and stakeholder needs

questions.Explenation: The Product Owner prioritizes backlog items based on value, risk, dependencies, and stakeholder priorities (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: When should retrospectives be held?

Choices.choicetext: At regular intervals, typically at the end of each iteration

questions.Explenation: Regular retrospectives enable continuous improvement by reflecting on what worked and what can be improved (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What should a Scrum Master do when the team encounters an impediment?

Choices.choicetext: Work to remove the impediment or escalate if beyond their authority
Ignore it if it's outside the Sprint

questions.Explenation: Scrum Masters are servant leaders who actively work to remove impediments that block the team's progress (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should project measurement be approached according to PMBOK 7?

Choices.choicetext: Measure what matters for decision-making and stakeholder needs

questions.Explenation: The Measurement Performance Domain emphasizes measuring meaningful metrics that support decisions and demonstrate value (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the benefit of co-located teams in agile?
questions.Explenation: Co-location enables osmotic communication, faster problem-solving, and stronger team bonds (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: When transitioning to agile, what is a recommended approach?

Choices.choicetext: Start with a pilot project and gradually expand practices
Fire all existing staff and hire agile experts

questions.Explenation: A gradual transition with pilot projects reduces risk and allows organizational learning (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What characterizes a self-organizing team?

Choices.choicetext: The team determines how to accomplish work without being directed

questions.Explenation: Self-organizing teams decide internally how to best accomplish their work within given boundaries (Agile Practice Guide; PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How should estimation be handled when there is high uncertainty?

Choices.choicetext: Use ranges or relative sizing rather than precise estimates

questions.Explenation: When uncertainty is high, ranges acknowledge variability; precise estimates create false confidence (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a Definition of Ready?

Choices.choicetext: To ensure backlog items are sufficiently understood before work begins

questions.Explenation: Definition of Ready establishes criteria for when a backlog item is refined enough for the team to work on (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should distributed/virtual teams maintain collaboration?

Choices.choicetext: Use video calls, shared tools, and overlapping work hours

questions.Explenation: Virtual teams need intentional collaboration using technology, overlapping hours, and regular communication (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: When is rolling wave planning most appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: When future work details are unknown and will be elaborated progressively
When the project has no phases

questions.Explenation: Rolling wave planning elaborates near-term work in detail while keeping future work at a higher level (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What role does the governance framework play in projects?

Choices.choicetext: Provides oversight, decision-making authority, and alignment with organizational strategy

questions.Explenation: Governance provides structure for oversight, decision-making, and ensuring alignment with strategy (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How should a project team handle technical debt?

Choices.choicetext: Track it, prioritize strategically, and address it incrementally

questions.Explenation: Technical debt should be visible, tracked, and addressed strategically to maintain system quality (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project using Scrum has consistently low velocity and missed Sprint goals. The team blames unclear requirements. What is the MOST likely root cause?

Choices.choicetext: Insufficient backlog refinement and poor Definition of Ready

questions.Explenation: Low velocity often stems from poor backlog refinement, leading to unclear stories entering Sprints (Agile Practice Guide, Section 5.2).

questions.QuestionText: An organization is transitioning from waterfall to agile. Several projects have failed. What organizational factor is most likely contributing?
questions.Explenation: Agile transformation requires organizational culture change; command-and-control leadership undermines self-organization (Agile Practice Guide, Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A Kanban team has work piling up in the 'Testing' column. What should they do FIRST?

Choices.choicetext: Stop starting new work and help clear the bottleneck
Add more columns to the board

questions.Explenation: When bottlenecks occur, team members should swarm to clear them rather than starting new work (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project team is working with multiple external vendors using fixed contracts while the internal team uses Scrum. What approach should be used?

Choices.choicetext: A hybrid approach with integration points between predictive vendor work and agile internal work
Force all vendors to use Scrum
Switch the internal team to waterfall

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches allow different parts of a project to use appropriate methods while maintaining integration (Agile Practice Guide, Section 3.1.6).

questions.QuestionText: During Sprint Review, stakeholders provide feedback that significantly changes the product direction. What should the team do?

Choices.choicetext: Work with the Product Owner to reprioritize the backlog based on the new direction
Ignore the feedback and continue as planned
File a formal complaint against the stakeholders

questions.Explenation: Sprint Reviews are designed to gather feedback; the Product Owner incorporates this into backlog prioritization (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project has both well-defined features and experimental R&D components. What approach is most appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: Use predictive approach for defined features and agile for R&D
Complete all R&D before starting features

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches allow matching methods to component characteristics - predictive for certainty, agile for uncertainty (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A team's velocity has been stable at 40 points for six Sprints. The Product Owner asks to commit to 60 points in the next Sprint due to a deadline. What should happen?

Choices.choicetext: Explain that exceeding historical velocity is risky and discuss alternative solutions
Commit to 60 points to satisfy the Product Owner
Remove quality checks to go faster

questions.Explenation: Sustainable pace is important; velocity reflects actual capacity and shouldn't be artificially inflated (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The project requires regulatory approval that takes 6 months. How should this be incorporated into an agile project?

Choices.choicetext: Plan for the regulatory milestone as a predictive element in a hybrid approach
Wait 6 months then start the project
Use agile to speed up regulatory approval

questions.Explenation: Fixed external dependencies can be handled as predictive elements while development proceeds iteratively (Agile Practice Guide, Section 3.1.9).

questions.QuestionText: A project manager discovers that quality issues are increasing as the team rushes to meet a deadline. What PMBOK 7 principle is most relevant?

Choices.choicetext: Build quality into processes and deliverables

questions.Explenation: The quality principle emphasizes that quality should be built in throughout, not inspected at the end or sacrificed for speed (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: Multiple teams are working on components of a large product. How should they coordinate?

Choices.choicetext: Establish integration points, shared cadence, and regular cross-team communication
Have one team do all integration at the end

questions.Explenation: Scaling agile requires coordination mechanisms like Scrum of Scrums, shared planning, and integration practices (Agile Practice Guide, Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A retrospective reveals the same problems Sprint after Sprint. What should the Scrum Master do?

Choices.choicetext: Facilitate root cause analysis and ensure improvement actions are actually implemented
Blame the team for not improving

questions.Explenation: Effective retrospectives require follow-through; recurring issues indicate improvements aren't being implemented (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project stakeholder wants daily detailed status reports. The agile team finds this disruptive. What approach balances these needs?

Choices.choicetext: Provide access to information radiators and adjust reporting frequency through negotiation
Write detailed reports daily as requested
Remove the stakeholder from the project

questions.Explenation: Information radiators provide transparency; stakeholder engagement requires finding mutually acceptable approaches (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).
