questions.QuestionText: The Definition of Done (DoD) doesn't include testing, and quality problems are appearing in production. What should the team do?

Choices.choicetext: Revise the Definition of Done to include appropriate testing standards
Add more Sprints for testing only

questions.Explenation: Definition of Done should ensure quality; if defects escape, DoD is inadequate and needs strengthening (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project has dependencies on another team that uses a different methodology. How should cross-team dependencies be managed?

Choices.choicetext: Identify dependencies early, establish communication protocols, and create integration milestones
Force the other team to change their methodology
Ignore the dependencies until they become problems
Wait for the other team to finish first

questions.Explenation: Cross-team dependencies require proactive management regardless of methodology differences (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An executive requests a detailed 18-month roadmap with specific feature dates. The project uses agile. What should the Product Owner provide?

Choices.choicetext: A high-level roadmap with themes and approximate timeframes, acknowledging uncertainty
An exact list of features with guaranteed dates

questions.Explenation: Agile planning provides vision and direction while acknowledging that details evolve; roadmaps should reflect this (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: According to PMBOK 7, when should system thinking be applied?

Choices.choicetext: Throughout the project to understand how components interact and affect outcomes

questions.Explenation: The principle of recognizing, evaluating, and responding to system interactions applies throughout the project (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team is using flow-based agile (Kanban). When should they release to production?

Choices.choicetext: When work items meet the Definition of Done and there is a business need
Only at the end of fixed iterations

questions.Explenation: Flow-based agile can release whenever items are ready, rather than waiting for iteration boundaries (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A complex project involves multiple stakeholders with conflicting requirements. What approach should the project manager take?

Choices.choicetext: Facilitate discussions to understand underlying needs and find solutions that maximize overall value
Choose the most powerful stakeholder's requirements
Implement all requirements regardless of conflicts

questions.Explenation: The stakeholder engagement principle involves working through conflicts to understand true needs and optimize value (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team has been using velocity for planning but recently added two new members. How should this affect Sprint planning?

Choices.choicetext: Expect velocity to decrease initially due to onboarding, then gradually increase

questions.Explenation: New team members require onboarding; capacity temporarily decreases before increasing (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: An agile project needs to integrate with legacy systems maintained by another department. What is the best approach?

Choices.choicetext: Establish clear interfaces, plan integration Sprints, and maintain ongoing communication
Wait until the agile project is complete

questions.Explenation: Legacy integration requires careful planning, clear interfaces, and collaboration between teams (Agile Practice Guide, hybrid approaches).

questions.QuestionText: An organization is scaling agile across multiple teams with interdependencies. Teams are experiencing integration failures and conflicting priorities. According to both PMBOK 7 and Agile Practice Guide, what is the most comprehensive solution?

Choices.choicetext: Implement a shared cadence, cross-team coordination events, integrated planning, and a governance structure that balances team autonomy with organizational alignment

questions.Explenation: Scaling agile requires coordination mechanisms, shared cadence, integration planning, and governance that respects agile principles (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A project is experiencing 'scope creep' despite using agile. The Product Owner accepts every stakeholder request. How does this violate PMBOK 7 principles and how should it be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: It violates the value focus principle; the PO should prioritize based on value, not just accept all requests, and maintain sustainable pace

questions.Explenation: The focus on value principle means prioritizing high-value work; accepting everything without prioritization undermines value delivery (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An enterprise is implementing SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework) but teams feel constrained and the Agile Manifesto values seem compromised. What tension exists and how should it be resolved?

Choices.choicetext: Framework overhead can conflict with agile values; the organization should tailor the framework to maintain agile principles while meeting coordination needs

questions.Explenation: Scaling frameworks must be tailored to preserve agile values; over-prescription can undermine the agile mindset (Agile Practice Guide; PMBOK 7 tailoring principle).

questions.QuestionText: A complex project has both high technical uncertainty (new technology) and high requirements uncertainty (unclear market). What development approach and governance structure is most appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: Agile with spike iterations for technical exploration, frequent customer validation, and adaptive governance with regular portfolio reviews

questions.Explenation: Double uncertainty requires approaches that reduce both technical and market risk through experimentation and validation (Agile Practice Guide; PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project team is geographically distributed across five time zones. How should the Measurement and Team Performance Domains be applied to maintain effectiveness?

Choices.choicetext: Use asynchronous communication tools, visual dashboards, intentional overlap hours for collaboration, and metrics focused on outcomes rather than activity
Require all team members to work the same hours

questions.Explenation: Distributed teams need intentional practices for collaboration and outcome-focused measurement (PMBOK Guide 7 Team and Measurement Performance Domains).

questions.QuestionText: During project execution, an emerging technology threatens to make the current solution obsolete. How do the principles of adaptability and value focus apply?

Choices.choicetext: Evaluate the technology's impact on project value, consider pivoting if the new technology delivers significantly more value, and engage stakeholders in the decision
Ignore the new technology and continue as planned
Wait until project completion to evaluate

questions.Explenation: The adaptability principle combined with value focus requires evaluating changes that could affect value delivery (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project has successfully delivered an increment, but stakeholders are disappointed with the business outcomes. What does this indicate according to PMBOK 7's outcome vs. output distinction?

Choices.choicetext: The project focused on outputs (deliverables) rather than outcomes (benefits); future work should emphasize value realization and benefit tracking
Output and outcome are the same

questions.Explenation: PMBOK 7 emphasizes outcomes over outputs; delivering features without achieving intended benefits indicates misalignment (PMBOK Guide 7 Delivery Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: An organization uses both agile projects and predictive programs. How should the portfolio governance integrate both approaches while maintaining strategic alignment?

Choices.choicetext: Establish unified value metrics, flexible milestone reviews for agile, traditional gate reviews for predictive, and portfolio-level outcome tracking
Force all projects to use the same approach

questions.Explenation: Portfolio governance must accommodate different approaches while maintaining strategic alignment and value focus (PMBOK Guide 7 governance section).

questions.QuestionText: A product is being developed incrementally. After five releases, the accumulated technical debt is slowing development significantly. How should this be addressed using PMBOK 7 principles?

Choices.choicetext: Apply the quality principle by allocating capacity for debt reduction, make debt visible in planning, and balance new features with sustainability

questions.Explenation: The quality principle requires sustainable practices; technical debt accumulation indicates quality isn't being built in (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project faces complex interdependencies between components owned by different teams. One team's delays cascade to others. How should the Project Work Performance Domain address this?

Choices.choicetext: Implement dependency management practices, buffer time between dependent work, visualize dependencies, and create escalation paths for blockers
Let each team handle their own problems

questions.Explenation: The Project Work Performance Domain includes establishing processes for managing work, including dependencies (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An agile team consistently delivers working software but business stakeholders remain disengaged. How does this relate to the Stakeholder Performance Domain?

Choices.choicetext: Effective stakeholder engagement requires active participation, not just receiving deliverables; the team should adjust engagement strategies to increase involvement
Stakeholder engagement is optional in agile

questions.Explenation: The Stakeholder Performance Domain emphasizes proactive engagement; passive stakeholders may indicate ineffective engagement strategies (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A program comprises multiple agile projects serving different customer segments. How should program-level benefits realization integrate with project-level incremental delivery?

Choices.choicetext: Establish benefits maps linking project increments to program outcomes, track leading indicators at project level and lagging benefits at program level
Wait until all projects complete to measure benefits

questions.Explenation: Benefits realization at multiple levels requires linking incremental delivery to program outcomes (PMBOK Guide 7; program management concepts).

questions.QuestionText: A project team proposes using an experimental approach (DevOps with continuous deployment) that leadership is unfamiliar with. How should the tailoring decision be made?

Choices.choicetext: Evaluate the approach against project needs, organizational readiness, and risks; pilot if appropriate, with clear success criteria and governance agreement

questions.Explenation: The tailoring principle requires evaluating approaches against context; new methods need appropriate governance and risk management (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project has achieved all its planned deliverables but the organization's strategic direction has shifted, making the deliverables less valuable. What does this illustrate about the relationship between projects and organizational strategy?

Choices.choicetext: Projects exist within a value delivery system; when strategy shifts, project value must be reassessed, potentially leading to scope changes, pivots, or closure
Complete the project regardless of value

questions.Explenation: PMBOK 7 emphasizes projects operate within a system for value delivery; misalignment with strategy diminishes value (PMBOK Guide 7 Section 2).

questions.QuestionText: An agile transformation is proceeding, but legacy systems and processes create friction. How should the change be managed according to both PMBOK 7 and Agile Practice Guide?

Choices.choicetext: Apply change management principles: build coalition, address resistance, create quick wins, and incrementally evolve systems while maintaining operations

questions.Explenation: The enable change principle applies to transformations; Agile Guide recommends incremental adoption (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: What is a project deliverable?

Choices.choicetext: Any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability produced during the project

questions.Explenation: A deliverable is any tangible or intangible output that the project produces (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a milestone in project management?

Choices.choicetext: A significant point or event in a project
A rock by the side of a road

questions.Explenation: A milestone marks a significant point in the project timeline, often representing completion of a major phase or deliverable.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a kickoff meeting?

Choices.choicetext: To officially start the project and align the team on objectives

questions.Explenation: A kickoff meeting brings stakeholders together to align on project objectives, roles, and expectations.

questions.QuestionText: What is a project constraint?

Choices.choicetext: A limiting factor that affects project execution

questions.Explenation: Constraints are factors that limit how a project can be executed, such as budget, time, or resources.

questions.QuestionText: What is a project assumption?

Choices.choicetext: Something considered to be true for planning purposes without proof

questions.Explenation: Assumptions are factors considered true for planning that may carry risk if proven false.

questions.QuestionText: What is backlog grooming (refinement)?

Choices.choicetext: The ongoing process of reviewing and preparing backlog items for future Sprints
Removing all items from the backlog

questions.Explenation: Backlog refinement is the activity of adding detail, estimates, and order to backlog items (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the primary goal of the Agile Manifesto?

Choices.choicetext: To value individuals, working software, collaboration, and responding to change

questions.Explenation: The Agile Manifesto establishes values that prioritize people, working products, collaboration, and adaptability (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is acceptance criteria?

Choices.choicetext: Conditions that must be met before a deliverable is accepted

questions.Explenation: Acceptance criteria define what must be true for a user story or deliverable to be considered complete and accepted.

questions.QuestionText: What does 'value' mean in project management context?

Choices.choicetext: The worth, importance, or usefulness of something to stakeholders

questions.Explenation: Value is worth or usefulness perceived by stakeholders - it can be financial, social, or other forms of benefit (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is an increment in agile?

Choices.choicetext: A working piece of the product that adds to previous increments

questions.Explenation: An increment is a potentially releasable output that adds to all prior increments (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is Extreme Programming (XP)?

Choices.choicetext: An agile methodology emphasizing technical practices like TDD and pair programming

questions.Explenation: XP is an agile framework focused on engineering practices like test-driven development and continuous integration (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a Sprint Goal?

Choices.choicetext: To provide focus and coherence for the Sprint

questions.Explenation: The Sprint Goal provides a single objective that gives the team flexibility while maintaining focus (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is complexity in project context?

Choices.choicetext: A characteristic of a project with many interconnected elements and unpredictable outcomes

questions.Explenation: Complexity refers to projects with many interrelated parts, emergent behaviors, and difficult-to-predict outcomes (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a project sponsor?

Choices.choicetext: A person who provides resources and support for the project and is accountable for success

questions.Explenation: The sponsor authorizes the project, provides resources, and champions it within the organization (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is a risk in project management?

Choices.choicetext: An uncertain event that could have positive or negative impact on the project

questions.Explenation: Risks are uncertain events that could affect project objectives positively (opportunities) or negatively (threats) (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is change control?

Choices.choicetext: A process for identifying, evaluating, and managing changes to project scope

questions.Explenation: Change control manages how changes to the project are identified, evaluated, approved, and tracked.

questions.QuestionText: What is scope in project management?

Choices.choicetext: The work that must be performed to deliver the project's products and services

questions.Explenation: Scope defines the boundaries of what the project will and will not deliver.

questions.QuestionText: What is the difference between a risk and an issue?

Choices.choicetext: A risk is uncertain and future; an issue is a current problem

questions.Explenation: Risks are potential future events; issues are problems that have already occurred and need resolution.

questions.QuestionText: What is stakeholder analysis?

Choices.choicetext: Identifying stakeholders and analyzing their interests, influence, and impact on the project

questions.Explenation: Stakeholder analysis helps understand who affects or is affected by the project (PMBOK Guide 7, Stakeholder Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: What is lessons learned?

Choices.choicetext: Knowledge gained during a project about what worked and what didn't

questions.Explenation: Lessons learned capture experiences to improve future projects and become organizational process assets.

questions.QuestionText: A team is consistently overcommitting in Sprint Planning. What is the most effective solution?

Choices.choicetext: Use historical velocity data and adjust capacity for known absences

questions.Explenation: Velocity-based planning using historical data provides realistic commitment levels (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should a project manager handle a stakeholder who constantly changes priorities?

Choices.choicetext: Work with them to understand underlying needs and establish a prioritization process

questions.Explenation: Stakeholder engagement involves understanding true needs and creating sustainable processes (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: When should a predictive project consider adding agile practices?

Choices.choicetext: When requirements are changing frequently or feedback cycles need to improve

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches can improve responsiveness when change is high (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What should the team do when a Sprint is almost complete but the Sprint Goal won't be achieved?

Choices.choicetext: Discuss with the Product Owner to adjust scope while maximizing value delivered

questions.Explenation: Sprint scope can be negotiated with the Product Owner; the Sprint timebox should not be extended (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should the project team respond when enterprise environmental factors change mid-project?

Choices.choicetext: Assess the impact, communicate with stakeholders, and adapt the approach if needed

questions.Explenation: The adaptability principle requires responding to environmental changes (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project delivers value in increments. When should benefits realization be measured?

Choices.choicetext: After each increment and on an ongoing basis as benefits materialize

questions.Explenation: Incremental delivery allows early benefits measurement; outcomes should be tracked as they occur (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A product owner is unavailable and the team needs direction. What should happen?

Choices.choicetext: Escalate to get a delegate or proxy who can make product decisions
Make all product decisions by team vote
Stop all work until PO returns

questions.Explenation: Product ownership decisions require business input; a proxy should be designated if the PO is unavailable (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should quality be integrated into an agile project?

Choices.choicetext: Build quality practices into every Sprint through testing, reviews, and Definition of Done
Add a testing Sprint at the end

questions.Explenation: Quality is built in throughout; the Definition of Done ensures quality standards are met (Agile Practice Guide; PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: When is a project considered successful according to PMBOK 7?

Choices.choicetext: When it delivers intended outcomes and value to stakeholders
When it's on time and budget only

questions.Explenation: PMBOK 7 emphasizes outcomes and value delivery, not just meeting constraints (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What should a Scrum team do when they discover a significant technical debt during a Sprint?

Choices.choicetext: Make it visible, discuss with the Product Owner, and plan to address it appropriately
Fix it all immediately regardless of Sprint goal

questions.Explenation: Technical debt should be visible and prioritized like other backlog items based on impact (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should conflicting stakeholder requirements be handled in an agile environment?

Choices.choicetext: The Product Owner facilitates prioritization based on value with stakeholder input

questions.Explenation: The Product Owner is responsible for backlog prioritization, resolving conflicts through stakeholder engagement (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A team is using velocity for forecasting. What factors should be considered when the forecast differs significantly from stakeholder expectations?

Choices.choicetext: Review scope, discuss trade-offs, and explore options like adding resources or reducing scope

questions.Explenation: Velocity provides realistic forecasts; when misaligned with expectations, scope or resource adjustments should be discussed.

questions.QuestionText: When transitioning from a functional organization to project-based work, what challenge is most likely?

Choices.choicetext: Resource conflicts between functional and project responsibilities

questions.Explenation: Functional organizations may struggle with resource allocation between departmental and project work (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How should the team handle user stories that are too large to complete in one Sprint?

Choices.choicetext: Break them into smaller stories that can be completed within the Sprint
Extend the Sprint to fit them
Assign them to an external team

questions.Explenation: Stories should be small enough to complete in one Sprint; large stories (epics) should be split (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the relationship between project principles and project processes?

Choices.choicetext: Principles guide behavior and decisions; processes are the activities used to deliver results

questions.Explenation: PMBOK 7 principles are foundational guidelines that inform how processes and methods are applied (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project is using SAFe at the enterprise level. Teams report feeling disconnected from business value and overly focused on process compliance. What PMBOK 7 principle is being violated?

Choices.choicetext: Focus on value - process should enable value delivery, not become an end in itself

questions.Explenation: When process compliance overshadows value delivery, it violates the focus on value principle (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An agile team is integrating with a vendor using fixed-price contracts. The vendor resists change requests. What hybrid approach addresses this?

Choices.choicetext: Define stable interfaces with the vendor, use a change control process, and isolate agile development from vendor dependencies
Force the vendor to use agile

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches accommodate different methods through stable interfaces and appropriate boundaries (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A retrospective reveals that the team feels pressured by management to increase velocity. This is affecting quality. How should the Scrum Master respond?

Choices.choicetext: Coach management on sustainable pace, explain the velocity misconception, and advocate for the team

questions.Explenation: The Scrum Master protects the team and educates stakeholders; velocity is a planning tool, not a performance metric (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A complex project has components with different risk profiles. How should the development approach be tailored?

Choices.choicetext: Use agile for high-risk/uncertain components and predictive for stable, well-understood components
Use the same approach for everything

questions.Explenation: Tailoring matches approach to component characteristics; higher uncertainty benefits from iterative approaches (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The planning performance domain emphasizes 'just enough' planning. How does this apply to an agile project with regulatory requirements?

Choices.choicetext: Plan enough to meet compliance requirements while maintaining agility for development work

questions.Explenation: 'Just enough' planning is context-dependent; regulated environments may require more documentation while preserving agile delivery (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project team discovers that a key assumption was incorrect mid-project. What should happen according to the Uncertainty Performance Domain?

Choices.choicetext: Reassess project risks, communicate to stakeholders, adjust plans, and update risk responses
Blame the person who made the assumption

questions.Explenation: Invalid assumptions represent materialized risks that require response and plan adjustment (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: Multiple product owners from different departments want to prioritize their own features. How should this be resolved in a scaled agile environment?

Choices.choicetext: Establish a portfolio-level prioritization process based on strategic value

questions.Explenation: Scaled agile requires coordination and unified prioritization based on organizational strategy (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A project team is struggling with scope creep in an agile context. What systemic issue might be causing this?

Choices.choicetext: Weak Product Owner authority or unclear product vision

questions.Explenation: Scope issues often stem from unclear ownership; the Product Owner must have authority to prioritize and say no (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should the Measurement Performance Domain be applied when tracking an innovative R&D project?

Choices.choicetext: Use learning-oriented metrics like validated hypotheses and pivot decisions rather than traditional progress metrics

questions.Explenation: Innovative projects benefit from metrics focused on learning and discovery rather than plan adherence (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team's velocity has decreased over several Sprints. Analysis shows increasing meetings and coordination overhead. What should be done?

Choices.choicetext: Streamline meetings, reduce dependencies, and focus on high-value coordination only
Add more meetings to address the issue

questions.Explenation: Overhead reduces capacity for value delivery; lean principles suggest eliminating waste in processes.

questions.QuestionText: An organization is experiencing 'agile anti-patterns' including fixed scope contracts with agile development, velocity targets as KPIs, and partial Scrum without retrospectives. What comprehensive organizational change is needed?

Choices.choicetext: Align contracts with agile values, educate leadership on proper metrics, restore full Scrum practices, and address organizational culture
Abandon agile and return to waterfall

questions.Explenation: Anti-patterns indicate misalignment between practices and principles; organizational change requires addressing root causes (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A portfolio contains projects with varying levels of strategic importance, risk, and development maturity. How should governance be tailored while maintaining strategic alignment?

Choices.choicetext: Risk-based governance with lighter oversight for mature, low-risk initiatives and closer governance for strategic, high-risk projects

questions.Explenation: Tailored governance matches oversight intensity to project characteristics while maintaining alignment (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project team must balance PMBOK 7's principle of 'building quality into processes' with pressure for rapid delivery in a startup environment. How should this tension be resolved?

Choices.choicetext: Define minimal quality standards that protect core functionality, accept calculated technical debt, and plan for debt reduction as the product matures

questions.Explenation: Quality should be context-appropriate; startups may accept more technical debt initially while planning for future improvement (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: An agile transformation has stalled. Teams adopted practices but business outcomes haven't improved. Analysis shows unchanged organizational structure, reward systems, and leadership behaviors. What does this indicate?

Choices.choicetext: Agile adoption failed to address enterprise-level changes needed for true transformation - it's doing agile without being agile
Teams need more training on practices

questions.Explenation: True agile transformation requires organizational culture, structure, and leadership change - not just practice adoption (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A project has succeeded in delivering all planned outputs but failed to achieve the expected business outcomes. Post-implementation review shows the original business case assumptions were flawed. How should this inform future projects?

Choices.choicetext: Validate business case assumptions earlier through incremental delivery and outcome measurement, treating assumptions as risks

questions.Explenation: Outcomes matter more than outputs; assumptions should be validated early through feedback loops (PMBOK Guide 7 Delivery Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: An organization is implementing both predictive programs and agile projects. Program managers complain that agile teams won't commit to long-term plans. What integration approach balances both needs?

Choices.choicetext: Establish planning horizons: commit to near-term deliverables, provide forecasts for medium-term, and roadmaps for long-term, with explicit assumptions and confidence levels
Force agile teams to provide fixed long-term commitments

questions.Explenation: Different planning horizons with appropriate commitment levels can satisfy both agile principles and program needs (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The Development Approach and Life Cycle Performance Domain suggests tailoring the approach. A project has elements that are highly innovative (uncertain technology), have regulatory requirements (fixed process), and require rapid market response (time-sensitive). What approach is optimal?

Choices.choicetext: Hybrid approach: agile for innovation, predictive for compliance, with coordination mechanisms and parallel tracks where possible

questions.Explenation: Complex projects benefit from hybrid approaches that match methods to specific component needs (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide Section 3.1).

questions.QuestionText: A project operates in a complex adaptive system where stakeholder expectations, regulatory environment, and technology are all evolving. How should the project apply the 'navigate complexity' principle?

Choices.choicetext: Use short feedback loops, maintain flexibility in approach, continuously monitor the environment, and be prepared to pivot based on emerging information

questions.Explenation: Complex environments require adaptive approaches with continuous learning and responsiveness (PMBOK Guide 7 navigate complexity principle).

questions.QuestionText: A mature agile team has stable velocity and predictable delivery but has become complacent. Retrospectives produce no actions, and innovation has declined. What intervention is needed?

Choices.choicetext: Introduce new challenges, rotate team members, set stretch goals, bring in external facilitation for retrospectives, and refocus on continuous improvement

questions.Explenation: High-performing teams can stagnate; continuous improvement requires intentional disruption and new challenges (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a project phase?

Choices.choicetext: A collection of logically related project activities that culminates in one or more deliverables

questions.Explenation: A project phase is a portion of the project where related activities produce specific deliverables (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the difference between efficiency and effectiveness in project management?

Choices.choicetext: Efficiency is doing things right; effectiveness is doing the right things

questions.Explenation: Efficiency focuses on resource optimization while effectiveness focuses on achieving desired outcomes.

questions.QuestionText: What is a product backlog item (PBI)?

Choices.choicetext: A single item of work to be done, such as a user story, bug fix, or task

questions.Explenation: A PBI is any item in the product backlog that represents work the team may do (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a project status report?

Choices.choicetext: To communicate project progress to stakeholders

questions.Explenation: Status reports provide stakeholders with current information about project progress, issues, and upcoming work.

questions.QuestionText: What is empiricism in agile?

Choices.choicetext: Making decisions based on observation and experience rather than theory

questions.Explenation: Empiricism in agile means learning through experience and making decisions based on what is observed (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a time and materials (T&M) contract?

Choices.choicetext: A contract where payment is based on actual time spent and materials used

questions.Explenation: T&M contracts pay for actual hours worked plus materials, providing flexibility when scope is uncertain.

questions.QuestionText: What is progressive elaboration?

Choices.choicetext: Developing project plans in greater detail as more information becomes available

questions.Explenation: Progressive elaboration means continuously improving and detailing plans as information emerges (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is swarming in agile?

Choices.choicetext: When multiple team members work together on a single item to complete it quickly

questions.Explenation: Swarming means the whole team focuses on one item until it's done, especially useful for blockers (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is an artifact in project management?

Choices.choicetext: A document, template, output, or deliverable produced during the project

questions.Explenation: Artifacts are tangible outputs of project work such as plans, reports, and deliverables (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of a demo in agile?

Choices.choicetext: To show working functionality to stakeholders and gather feedback
To play music for the team

questions.Explenation: Demos show completed work to stakeholders, enabling early feedback and validation (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a blocker in agile?

Choices.choicetext: An impediment that prevents the team from making progress

questions.Explenation: A blocker is an issue preventing progress; it's the Scrum Master's responsibility to help remove it (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is the Iron Law of Projects?

Choices.choicetext: You can have it fast, cheap, or good - pick two
Iron must be used in construction
All projects take the same time

questions.Explenation: This principle highlights trade-offs between time, cost, and quality constraints.

questions.QuestionText: What is a stakeholder register?

Choices.choicetext: A document listing project stakeholders and relevant information about them

questions.Explenation: The stakeholder register contains details about stakeholders including their interests, influence, and engagement needs.

questions.QuestionText: What is the difference between lead time and cycle time?

Choices.choicetext: Lead time is from request to delivery; cycle time is from work start to completion

questions.Explenation: Lead time includes waiting time; cycle time measures only active work time (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a fixed-price contract?

Choices.choicetext: A contract where the price is set regardless of actual costs incurred
A contract that can never change

questions.Explenation: Fixed-price contracts set a firm price for defined work, transferring cost risk to the seller.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of daily standups being time-boxed to 15 minutes?

Choices.choicetext: To keep the meeting focused and encourage quick coordination

questions.Explenation: Short timeboxes ensure standups remain focused on coordination, not detailed problem-solving (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What does 'transparency' mean in Scrum?

Choices.choicetext: Making work visible and honest so decisions can be based on accurate information
Using clear glass in the office

questions.Explenation: Transparency is a Scrum pillar meaning significant aspects of work must be visible to those responsible for outcomes (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What is a Sprint Backlog?

Choices.choicetext: The set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint plus the plan for delivering them
Items left over from previous Sprints

questions.Explenation: The Sprint Backlog contains the items the team commits to complete during the Sprint (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team notices that technical debt is slowing down new feature development. How should this be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Make technical debt visible in the backlog and allocate regular capacity for debt reduction
Ignore it and focus only on new features
Rewrite the entire system from scratch
Fire the developers who created the debt

questions.Explenation: Technical debt should be visible and managed like other work items, with regular investment in reduction (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A key team member is leaving the project. What should the project manager do first?

Choices.choicetext: Assess the impact and identify knowledge transfer needs
Nothing - people leave all the time

questions.Explenation: The Team Performance Domain emphasizes managing transitions and knowledge continuity (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: Stakeholders are requesting features that don't align with the product vision. What should the Product Owner do?

Choices.choicetext: Explain the product vision and help stakeholders understand how their needs can be met differently
Add all requested features to the backlog

questions.Explenation: The Product Owner maintains product vision and helps stakeholders understand prioritization decisions (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A team has completed all planned work but finds issues in production. What agile principle is most relevant?

Choices.choicetext: Building quality in - testing and quality practices should be strengthened

questions.Explenation: Production defects indicate quality wasn't built in throughout development (Agile Practice Guide; PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: The project schedule is slipping. What should the project manager analyze first?

Choices.choicetext: The critical path to identify which activities are causing delays

questions.Explenation: The critical path determines which delays affect the project end date (PMBOK Guide 7, Planning Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: During a retrospective, the team identifies that requirements are often unclear. What process should be improved?

Choices.choicetext: Backlog refinement to ensure stories meet Definition of Ready before Sprints

questions.Explenation: Unclear requirements indicate insufficient refinement; Definition of Ready ensures stories are well-prepared (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project has multiple external dependencies that could delay delivery. How should these be managed?

Choices.choicetext: Identify dependencies early, track them, communicate regularly with dependency owners, and have contingency plans
Only address them when they become problems

questions.Explenation: Dependencies are risks that require proactive management and communication (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: The team is having difficulty estimating complex user stories. What technique can help?

Choices.choicetext: Spike - a timeboxed research activity to reduce uncertainty

questions.Explenation: Spikes allow teams to explore unknowns before committing to delivery estimates (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: An executive asks why the agile team can't provide exact delivery dates for features planned 6 months out. How should this be explained?

Choices.choicetext: Agile provides forecasts with confidence ranges; certainty increases as features approach development
Dates will be provided when forced

questions.Explenation: Agile acknowledges uncertainty; longer-term forecasts are less certain but improve as work approaches (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team has completed testing but the Product Owner hasn't reviewed the increment. What should happen?

Choices.choicetext: The work shouldn't be considered done until it meets the Definition of Done including PO review
Skip the review for this Sprint

questions.Explenation: If PO review is in the Definition of Done, work isn't complete without it (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A vendor is consistently late delivering components. What contract modification might help?

Choices.choicetext: Add performance incentives and penalties tied to delivery milestones
Remove all deadlines from the contract

questions.Explenation: Contract terms can align vendor behavior with project needs through appropriate incentives (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: How should scope changes be handled in an agile project?

Choices.choicetext: Through backlog prioritization - new items compete for priority and lower items may be dropped
Changes require formal change control board approval

questions.Explenation: Agile welcomes changes through backlog management, balancing new requests against capacity (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A team is using both Scrum and XP practices. Is this appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: Yes - blending practices from multiple frameworks is common and encouraged when it benefits the team
No - you must use only one framework

questions.Explenation: Teams commonly blend practices from Scrum, XP, and Kanban to create effective approaches (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The Measurement Performance Domain recommends measuring what matters. How does a team determine what matters?

Choices.choicetext: Identify metrics that drive decisions and indicate progress toward outcomes
Use only metrics from past projects

questions.Explenation: Metrics should be chosen based on their ability to inform decisions and track outcome achievement (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A remote team member is consistently offline during daily standups. How should this be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Work with the team member to find a time that works for all or establish async standup alternatives

questions.Explenation: Distributed teams need to find inclusive practices that work across time zones (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should a project manager handle a conflict between two team members?

Choices.choicetext: Facilitate a discussion to understand perspectives and find a mutually acceptable resolution
Ignore it and hope it resolves
Always side with the more senior person

questions.Explenation: The Team Performance Domain includes conflict resolution skills (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project is 80% complete when a major change request is submitted. What factors should be considered?

Choices.choicetext: Impact on remaining work, sunk costs vs. value of change, stakeholder needs, and project constraints

questions.Explenation: Late changes require careful impact analysis weighing value against costs and risks.

questions.QuestionText: The Product Owner is struggling to prioritize an overwhelming backlog. What can help?

Choices.choicetext: Use value-based prioritization techniques and consider removing low-value items
Add more items to the backlog

questions.Explenation: Backlog management includes pruning low-value items and using techniques like MoSCoW or Kano (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A stakeholder insists on daily written status reports. The team uses an information radiator. What compromise can work?

Choices.choicetext: Provide access to the radiator and a brief weekly summary, explaining the benefits of real-time visibility
Write detailed daily reports as demanded

questions.Explenation: Stakeholder engagement requires balancing needs with team efficiency (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An agile team has been given a fixed deadline and fixed scope. How can agile still add value?

Choices.choicetext: Use iterative development for feedback, prioritize highest-value features first, and manage risk through early delivery
Agile cannot work with fixed constraints

questions.Explenation: Even with fixed constraints, agile practices provide value through early feedback and risk reduction (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project has experienced scope creep, schedule delays, and budget overruns. The sponsor wants to know why governance failed. What systemic issues should be examined?

Choices.choicetext: Change control processes, escalation procedures, monitoring effectiveness, and stakeholder engagement

questions.Explenation: Governance failures often indicate systemic issues in processes and controls (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An agile team is part of a larger waterfall program. The program manager requires detailed gantt charts and milestone tracking. How should the agile team comply while maintaining agility?

Choices.choicetext: Map Sprint deliverables to program milestones and provide velocity-based forecasts in gantt format

questions.Explenation: Agile teams can translate their artifacts for traditional reporting while maintaining agile practices (Agile Practice Guide hybrid section).

questions.QuestionText: The team's Definition of Done has evolved to include automated testing, code review, and documentation. Some legacy components don't meet this standard. What should be done?

Choices.choicetext: Apply the new DoD to new work; create a plan to incrementally bring legacy components up to standard
Lower the DoD to match legacy standards

questions.Explenation: Quality standards should be maintained for new work while legacy is improved incrementally (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project is using predictive methods, but requirements are changing rapidly. The team wants to shift to agile mid-project. What risks should be considered?

Choices.choicetext: Team readiness, stakeholder acceptance, contract compatibility, sunk costs in existing artifacts, and transition overhead
No risks - agile is always better

questions.Explenation: Mid-project transitions carry risks that must be evaluated against potential benefits (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: Two Scrum teams are building components of the same product but have different Definitions of Done. What problem might this cause?

Choices.choicetext: Integration issues and inconsistent quality when components are combined
No problems - each team is independent

questions.Explenation: Product-level DoD ensures integration quality; inconsistent standards create defects (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team has high velocity but stakeholder satisfaction is low. What might be happening?

Choices.choicetext: The team is delivering features but not the right features or not delivering value
Velocity is always a good indicator

questions.Explenation: Velocity measures output, not outcomes; high velocity without value delivery indicates misalignment with stakeholder needs.

questions.QuestionText: A complex project requires expertise that no single vendor has. How should the procurement strategy address this?

Choices.choicetext: Multi-vendor strategy with clear interfaces, integration management, and collaborative governance
Delay until one vendor can do everything

questions.Explenation: Complex projects often require multiple vendors with careful integration management (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: The uncertainty performance domain emphasizes exploring ambiguity. A project faces both known and unknown risks. How should these be differently managed?

Choices.choicetext: Known risks: specific response plans. Unknown risks: management reserve, resilient designs, and frequent monitoring for emerging risks
All risks are managed the same way

questions.Explenation: Unknown risks require different strategies including reserves and adaptive practices (PMBOK Guide 7 Uncertainty Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: A project is using earned value management but the numbers don't reflect reality because work is not easily measured. What alternative should be considered?

Choices.choicetext: Use outcome-based metrics, trend analysis, and qualitative assessments appropriate for the work type
Force EVM onto all work regardless

questions.Explenation: The Measurement Performance Domain emphasizes using appropriate metrics for the work type (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A retrospective reveals that junior developers are hesitant to speak up when they see problems. What team dysfunction does this indicate and how should it be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Lack of psychological safety; the Scrum Master should facilitate creating a safer environment for all voices

questions.Explenation: Psychological safety enables innovation and problem identification; it must be actively cultivated (PMBOK Guide 7 Team Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: A Kanban team notices that items frequently move backward on the board (from Done back to In Progress). What does this indicate?

Choices.choicetext: Quality issues or unclear acceptance criteria causing rework

questions.Explenation: Backward movement indicates rework, typically from quality escapes or unclear requirements.

questions.QuestionText: According to the system interaction principle in PMBOK 7, a project is experiencing unexpected delays because a dependent system was updated. How could this have been prevented?

Choices.choicetext: Better understanding of system interdependencies and establishing communication with dependent system teams

questions.Explenation: System thinking requires understanding and managing interdependencies (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team using flow-based agile notices that cycle time is increasing despite stable WIP. What should be investigated?

Choices.choicetext: Complexity of items, hidden queues, blocked items, and dependencies

questions.Explenation: Increasing cycle time with stable WIP suggests hidden blockers or changing work complexity.

questions.QuestionText: The Project Work Performance Domain emphasizes managing knowledge. How should lessons learned be captured in an agile project?

Choices.choicetext: Through regular retrospectives with actions documented and shared, plus ongoing improvements to practices

questions.Explenation: Agile captures learning continuously through retrospectives and shared practices (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project has significant regulatory requirements that mandate specific documentation and approval processes. How can agile practices still be applied?

Choices.choicetext: Use agile for development while integrating required documentation as part of the Definition of Done

questions.Explenation: Hybrid approaches can satisfy regulatory requirements while maintaining agile development practices.

questions.QuestionText: An organization's PMO mandates a single methodology for all projects. Teams with different contexts are struggling. How should this be addressed using PMBOK 7 principles?

Choices.choicetext: Apply the tailoring principle: establish a flexible framework that allows context-appropriate adaptation while maintaining organizational consistency
All teams must use identical approaches
Let each team do whatever they want

questions.Explenation: The tailoring principle supports context-appropriate approaches within organizational guidelines (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A large transformation program involves multiple workstreams: IT development (agile), infrastructure deployment (predictive), and organizational change (iterative). How should program-level coordination work?

Choices.choicetext: Establish common integration points, aligned cadences where possible, unified risk management, and governance that respects each approach's characteristics
Force all workstreams to use the same approach

questions.Explenation: Multi-approach programs require coordination that accommodates different methods (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide hybrid section).

questions.QuestionText: A project successfully delivered features but the expected business case ROI hasn't materialized after 6 months. The project was considered 'on time and on budget.' What does this reveal about project success measurement?

Choices.choicetext: Traditional success criteria (time, budget) are insufficient; outcome and benefit realization tracking should extend beyond project closure
Benefits appear later for all projects

questions.Explenation: PMBOK 7 emphasizes outcomes over outputs; benefit realization may require extended tracking (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A scaled agile implementation uses a release train with quarterly planning. Teams struggle with dependencies, and quarterly plans rarely survive first contact with reality. What fundamental issue should be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Reduce dependencies through architectural changes, increase planning frequency for dependent work, and improve continuous feedback loops
Plan more detailed quarters in advance
Force teams to meet the plan

questions.Explenation: Dependencies create fragile plans; reducing dependencies and increasing feedback improves adaptability (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The Delivery Performance Domain focuses on value delivery. A project has been delivering features for a year but business metrics haven't improved. What system-level analysis is needed?

Choices.choicetext: Evaluate the value hypothesis, feature adoption, usage analytics, and alignment between what's delivered and actual business needs

questions.Explenation: Value delivery requires not just outputting features but ensuring they create intended outcomes (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An organization is adopting agile but middle management feels threatened by empowered teams and reduced control. How should this organizational challenge be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Redefine middle management roles to add value in new ways: coaching, removing obstacles, strategic alignment, and cross-team coordination

questions.Explenation: Agile transformation requires role evolution, not elimination; managers must find new value-adding roles (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A project portfolio contains both 'keep the lights on' maintenance projects and innovative strategic initiatives. How should resources be allocated between them?

Choices.choicetext: Use portfolio balancing with explicit allocation decisions, protect innovation capacity, and measure both operational stability and strategic progress
Give all resources to urgent maintenance

questions.Explenation: Portfolio management balances operational needs with strategic investments (PMBOK Guide 7 value delivery system).

questions.QuestionText: Multiple teams are working on microservices for the same platform. Each team has autonomous DevOps practices, but integration failures are frequent. What governance approach maintains autonomy while ensuring quality?

Choices.choicetext: Establish shared contracts, automated integration testing, common deployment standards, and regular integration points while preserving team autonomy for internal practices

questions.Explenation: Decentralized development requires shared standards at integration points (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide scaling).

questions.QuestionText: A project team consistently underestimates work and overcommits. Retrospectives haven't fixed the pattern. What deeper organizational or psychological factor might be contributing?

Choices.choicetext: Pressure to commit to stakeholder expectations, optimism bias, or punishment for 'failing' to meet commitments discouraging honesty
This is normal for all teams

questions.Explenation: Systemic overcommitment often indicates organizational pressure that discourages realistic planning.

questions.QuestionText: The Development Approach Performance Domain suggests matching approaches to context. A project has both safety-critical components (requiring formal verification) and user interface components (requiring rapid iteration). How should this be architected?

Choices.choicetext: Separate concerns architecturally: safety-critical core with formal methods, UI layer with agile iteration, and clear interfaces between them

questions.Explenation: Architectural separation allows appropriate methods for different components (PMBOK Guide 7 tailoring; Agile Practice Guide hybrid).

questions.QuestionText: An enterprise agile transformation has been running for 2 years. Teams are practicing Scrum, but enterprise funding is still annual, HR evaluates individual performance, and architecture is centrally controlled. What pattern does this represent?

Choices.choicetext: Surface-level adoption: agile practices without organizational structure alignment, limiting true agility
This is the final state of agile

questions.Explenation: True agility requires alignment across practices, structures, funding, and HR systems (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A team must balance the PMBOK 7 principle of 'optimize risk responses' with the agile value of 'responding to change.' A significant risk has been identified that could derail the project. How should planning and agility be balanced?

Choices.choicetext: Develop contingency plans for the risk while maintaining flexibility through iterative development and regular reassessment as more information emerges
Ignore the risk since agile responds to change
Create detailed plans for all scenarios
Stop the project until risk is eliminated

questions.Explenation: Risk management and agility complement each other: plan for known risks while staying adaptive (PMBOK Guide 7; Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A team member suggests skipping Sprint Planning because the backlog is well-refined. Is this appropriate?

Choices.choicetext: No - Sprint Planning serves multiple purposes including team commitment and Sprint Goal creation
Only if the Scrum Master agrees

questions.Explenation: Sprint Planning is not just about selecting items; it creates shared understanding and commitment (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team has been asked to double their velocity for an important deadline. What is the appropriate response?

Choices.choicetext: Explain that velocity is a measure of past performance, not a target, and discuss realistic options

questions.Explenation: Velocity reflects capacity; artificially increasing it undermines planning accuracy (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: What should happen when the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete mid-Sprint?

Choices.choicetext: The Product Owner should consider canceling the Sprint

questions.Explenation: Only the Product Owner can cancel a Sprint, which may happen if the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: A project needs to integrate an external API. How should this dependency be handled in Sprint Planning?

Choices.choicetext: Identify the dependency explicitly, account for integration risk, and plan for potential delays
Assume the API will work perfectly
Build the feature without the API

questions.Explenation: External dependencies are risks that should be explicitly managed in planning.

questions.QuestionText: How should the project team handle work that spans multiple Sprints?

Choices.choicetext: Break it into Sprint-sized increments that each deliver some value
Work on it in parallel with other Sprints

questions.Explenation: Large work items should be split into increments that can be completed within Sprints (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team has completed all Sprint items early. What should they do?

Choices.choicetext: Pull additional items from the prioritized backlog with the Product Owner
Stretch current work to fill time

questions.Explenation: Early completion is an opportunity to deliver more value by pulling additional prioritized work.

questions.QuestionText: A stakeholder asks why the agile team produces less documentation. How should this be explained?

Choices.choicetext: Agile values working software over comprehensive documentation, but produces documentation as needed

questions.Explenation: The Agile Manifesto values working software MORE than documentation, not instead of it (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should a product roadmap be used in agile planning?

Choices.choicetext: As a strategic guide showing direction and themes, not as a fixed commitment
As an exact schedule of features

questions.Explenation: Roadmaps provide direction while acknowledging that details will evolve (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The team's flow efficiency (active time vs. total time) is only 20%. What does this indicate?

Choices.choicetext: Items spend most of their time waiting in queues - focus on reducing wait time
Add more work items to fill time

questions.Explenation: Low flow efficiency indicates too much waiting; reducing WIP and bottlenecks improves flow.

questions.QuestionText: What is the appropriate level of detail for items at the top vs. bottom of the backlog?

Choices.choicetext: Top items should be detailed and sprint-ready; bottom items can be less refined
All items should be fully detailed
Bottom items should be most detailed

questions.Explenation: Progressive elaboration refines items as they approach development (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: An impediment is identified that requires organizational change to resolve. What should the Scrum Master do?

Choices.choicetext: Escalate appropriately and advocate for the change while protecting the team
Ignore it - organizational issues aren't their concern
Tell the team to work around it forever

questions.Explenation: Scrum Masters remove impediments, which may require escalation and advocacy (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should cross-team dependencies be visualized and managed?

Choices.choicetext: Use dependency boards, regular cross-team syncs, and track blockers explicitly

questions.Explenation: Dependency management requires visibility and communication mechanisms.

questions.QuestionText: A Sprint Review shows features that work but don't match stakeholder expectations. What process might be failing?

Choices.choicetext: Stakeholder involvement in refinement and acceptance criteria definition

questions.Explenation: Misaligned expectations often indicate insufficient stakeholder engagement in requirements.

questions.QuestionText: The Scrum Master notices that retrospective actions are not being implemented. What should they do?

Choices.choicetext: Follow up on actions, make them visible, and help the team understand the value of improvements

questions.Explenation: Retrospective value comes from implementing improvements, not just identifying them.

questions.QuestionText: A project requires work from specialists who aren't available full-time. How should this be handled?

Choices.choicetext: Plan work around specialist availability, minimize handoffs, and consider cross-training
Delay until specialists are fully available

questions.Explenation: Resource constraints require planning and may suggest cross-training opportunities.

questions.QuestionText: The team wants to change their Sprint length. What factors should be considered?

Choices.choicetext: Feedback frequency needs, ability to deliver increments, risk tolerance, and stakeholder availability

questions.Explenation: Sprint length is a tailoring decision based on context (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should value be demonstrated to stakeholders in agile?

Choices.choicetext: Through working increments, measurable outcomes, and regular feedback sessions

questions.Explenation: Agile demonstrates value through working deliverables and outcome metrics.

questions.QuestionText: What is the purpose of having a product vision?

Choices.choicetext: To provide direction and context for prioritization decisions

questions.Explenation: Product vision guides strategic direction and helps prioritize what to build (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: How should non-functional requirements be handled in agile?

Choices.choicetext: Include them in the Definition of Done or as specific backlog items
Ignore them - agile is only for features

questions.Explenation: Non-functional requirements like performance and security should be addressed throughout development.

questions.QuestionText: The team consistently delivers what's planned but rarely exceeds expectations. How might performance improve?

Choices.choicetext: Focus on continuous improvement, experiment with new practices, and challenge comfortable patterns
This is the best possible performance

questions.Explenation: Continuous improvement is a core agile principle; teams should challenge themselves to grow.

questions.QuestionText: An organization's annual budgeting cycle conflicts with agile's incremental funding needs. What approach can bridge this gap?

Choices.choicetext: Annual capacity funding with portfolio-level reallocation flexibility throughout the year
Fund projects monthly regardless of organization

questions.Explenation: Capacity-based funding provides stability while allowing agile prioritization (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: The team's burndown chart shows a plateau mid-Sprint. What should the Scrum Master investigate?

Choices.choicetext: Blockers, wait states, dependencies, or work items larger than estimated
Add more work to the Sprint

questions.Explenation: Plateaus indicate work isn't progressing; investigation reveals hidden impediments.

questions.QuestionText: A team practices continuous deployment but production incidents have increased. What quality practices might be missing?

Choices.choicetext: Automated testing, feature flags, canary releases, or adequate monitoring

questions.Explenation: Continuous deployment requires supporting practices to maintain quality (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The project operates in multiple regulatory jurisdictions with conflicting requirements. How should requirements management handle this?

Choices.choicetext: Map requirements by jurisdiction, identify conflicts, seek legal guidance, and build flexible architecture

questions.Explenation: Regulatory complexity requires careful analysis and architectural flexibility.

questions.QuestionText: Two teams have conflicting architectural approaches for shared components. How should this be resolved?

Choices.choicetext: Facilitate an architectural decision with both teams, document the decision, and align on shared standards
Let each team build their own version

questions.Explenation: Shared components require collaborative architectural decisions.

questions.QuestionText: A retrospective reveals systemic issues that the team cannot fix (e.g., insufficient tooling budget). How should these be handled?

Choices.choicetext: Document the impact, escalate to appropriate levels, track as organizational impediment, and continue advocating
Stop mentioning issues the team can't fix
Make do without proper tools forever

questions.Explenation: Organizational impediments require escalation and persistent advocacy.

questions.QuestionText: Metrics show the team is meeting all process metrics but customer satisfaction is declining. What does this indicate?

Choices.choicetext: Process metrics don't correlate with outcomes; add customer value metrics

questions.Explenation: Metrics should connect to customer value; process metrics alone can miss the point (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A critical team member has become a bottleneck - everything requires their input. What should be done?

Choices.choicetext: Cross-train other team members, document knowledge, and distribute decision-making
Add more work to their queue

questions.Explenation: Key person dependencies create risk; knowledge should be distributed.

questions.QuestionText: The Planning Performance Domain emphasizes appropriate estimation. When should the team re-estimate remaining work?

Choices.choicetext: When significant new information emerges that changes the understanding of remaining work
Only when estimates are too low

questions.Explenation: Estimates should be updated when learning changes understanding (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A project manager notices that decisions made in meetings are frequently reversed later. What governance issue might exist?

Choices.choicetext: Unclear decision authority, missing stakeholders, or poor decision documentation

questions.Explenation: Reversed decisions indicate governance problems that should be addressed (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: The team wants to adopt new engineering practices (e.g., TDD) but management is concerned about short-term velocity impact. How should this be handled?

Choices.choicetext: Explain the investment nature, quantify expected long-term benefits, and propose a gradual introduction

questions.Explenation: Practice changes should be justified with expected benefits and managed transparently.

questions.QuestionText: Multiple agile teams are building a platform with shared architecture. How should architectural decisions be made?

Choices.choicetext: Community of practice or architectural guild that involves representatives from each team

questions.Explenation: Shared architecture requires collaborative governance that involves teams (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A Scrum team's velocity is significantly lower than a similar team. Should they match the other team's velocity?

Choices.choicetext: No - velocity is team-specific and depends on many factors; compare outcomes not velocity
Yes - all teams should have equal velocity
Increase story point estimates to match

questions.Explenation: Velocity is relative to each team's estimation and context; cross-team comparison is meaningless (Agile Practice Guide).

questions.QuestionText: The project is delivering value but creating significant technical debt. Stakeholders are happy now. What should the team communicate?

Choices.choicetext: Make the debt visible, explain future cost/risk implications, and propose a sustainable approach
Keep stakeholders happy by hiding the debt
Technical debt is not a stakeholder concern
Stop delivering value to fix all debt

questions.Explenation: Transparency about technical debt enables informed decisions (PMBOK Guide 7 stewardship principle).

questions.QuestionText: A remote team member consistently misses deadlines but claims communication issues. How should this be investigated?

Choices.choicetext: Assess communication effectiveness, tooling, time zone challenges, and team integration practices

questions.Explenation: Remote work challenges require investigation and support before judgment (PMBOK Guide 7 Team Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: An organization has implemented agile at the team level for 3 years but enterprise-level processes (budgeting, governance, HR) remain unchanged. The VP asks why promised agility benefits aren't materializing. What explanation applies?

Choices.choicetext: Agile at team level without enterprise alignment creates friction that prevents full benefits - true agility requires systemic change
Agile only works for small organizations

questions.Explenation: Enterprise agility requires alignment across all systems, not just development practices (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: A program has agile projects with quarterly release trains. During PI planning, dependent teams discover their work doesn't align. What fundamental planning issue does this reveal?

Choices.choicetext: Insufficient pre-planning, poor backlog alignment across teams, or inadequate dependency management between planning cycles

questions.Explenation: Large-scale planning requires preparation and alignment before events (Agile Practice Guide Section 6).

questions.QuestionText: The PMBOK 7 principle of 'enable change to achieve the envisioned future state' conflicts with an organization's risk-averse culture that resists change. How should a project operating in this environment apply the principle?

Choices.choicetext: Start with small, low-risk changes; demonstrate benefits; build confidence; and gradually expand change scope

questions.Explenation: Change enablement must be tailored to organizational readiness (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: An agile project has been running for 18 months. The original product vision has been achieved but the team continues operating without clear direction. What organizational pattern is this?

Choices.choicetext: Project-to-product transition failure - the team should either have a new vision or transition to a product model

questions.Explenation: Projects have end states; continued operation without vision may indicate a need for product management model.

questions.QuestionText: Analysis shows that 70% of features developed are rarely or never used by customers. What systemic failure does this represent and how should it be addressed?

Choices.choicetext: Product discovery failure - implement techniques like customer research, MVPs, and outcome validation before full development

questions.Explenation: Unused features indicate poor understanding of customer needs; product discovery practices address this.

questions.QuestionText: Multiple stakeholders want dashboard metrics that support their individual goals but would create conflicting incentives across teams. How should this be resolved using PMBOK 7's systems thinking?

Choices.choicetext: Identify shared outcomes, align metrics to system-level goals, and help stakeholders see how local optimization hurts overall value
Give each stakeholder their preferred metrics

questions.Explenation: Systems thinking recognizes that local optimization can harm overall performance (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A team has achieved technical excellence with automated testing and continuous deployment but struggles with product direction. What capability gap exists?

Choices.choicetext: Product management - technical practices support delivery but product discovery ensures the right things are built

questions.Explenation: Building things right AND right things are both necessary; product capabilities complement engineering.

questions.QuestionText: During organizational restructuring, agile teams are broken apart and reassembled. After 6 months, productivity remains low. What team dynamic explains this?

Choices.choicetext: Teams went through forming-storming-norming stages again; high performance takes time to rebuild after disruption
Individual skills are all that matter

questions.Explenation: Disrupting teams restarts team development stages; stable teams perform better (PMBOK Guide 7 Team Performance Domain).

questions.QuestionText: A portfolio contains both 'exploit' (optimize existing) and 'explore' (innovate new) initiatives. The same governance is applied to both. What problem might this cause?

Choices.choicetext: Explore initiatives may be killed by ROI metrics appropriate for exploit; they need different success criteria and governance
Explore initiatives should have stricter ROI requirements

questions.Explenation: Innovation and optimization require different governance approaches and metrics.

questions.QuestionText: The Stakeholder Performance Domain emphasizes engagement. A project has successfully identified stakeholders but engagement activities feel performative without real influence. What is missing?

Choices.choicetext: Authentic engagement where stakeholder input genuinely influences decisions, not just communication theater

questions.Explenation: Engagement must be authentic and influential, not just procedural (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A scaled agile implementation has a central architecture team that reviews all designs. Teams report delays and frustration. What alternative governance model might work better?

Choices.choicetext: Embedded architects in teams, lightweight architectural principles, and peer review for significant decisions

questions.Explenation: Centralized gates create bottlenecks; distributed expertise with principles scales better.

questions.QuestionText: A project succeeded by PMBOK 7 outcome measures (value delivered, stakeholder satisfaction) but failed traditional measures (over budget, late). How should this be reported to executives?

Choices.choicetext: Present both perspectives: acknowledge constraint overruns while highlighting value delivered and lessons about estimation and scope management

questions.Explenation: Transparent reporting covers all perspectives; success is multidimensional (PMBOK Guide 7).

questions.QuestionText: A new team member is unfamiliar with agile. How should onboarding be handled?

Choices.choicetext: Pair them with experienced members, explain team practices, and give time to learn
Send them to a week-long training
Let them figure it out alone
